review: Reviewed 9.3.21  This film recently appeared on a list of top 25 all-time action movies.  And if action is simply what you're after, mission accomplished.  Tom Cruise continues his run of insane stunts, this time jumping solo from 30,000 feet.  While the rest of the white-knuckled action is spread throughout the ever-expanding cast of MI characters.   The most notable additions in this installment are Vanessa Kirby as a mysterious intermediary, and Henry Cavill as a supposed CIA hitmen that plays more like an alpha male meathead. Kirby adds to what was already a phenomenal female talent pool, and for my money, is the real reason to continue to give these movies a chance.  Kudos to Cruise and the MI producers for helming a series that offers up female roles on par with their male counterparts.  And within the storylines themselves, it's the femmes that truly rule this former boys club, and the entire production is better for it.   Unfortunately the main storyline of a nuclear arsenal gone rouge falls flat.  Been there, done that.  After a slow start dominated by unnecessary mansplaining of the overly convoluted plot, things eventually settle in.  And they do mostly stick the landing, with an ending that wisely returns to the emotional bond of the MI core.

review: The best Mission: Impossible movie and one of the best action movies. Fallout delivers on every category: the action sequences are the best of the franchise and there are so many standouts like the HALO jump, bathroom fight, Paris chase, rooftop chase and the helicopter chase. Each action scene is better than the previous and they build up in intensity. Every actor delivers excellent performances, it was great seeing Julia and Ethan's relationship developed, it's perfectly paced and structured and it's a thrilling ride that leaves you on the edge of your seat even if it's predictable. The score is also absolutely phenomenal and truly carries a lot of scenes and McQuarrie really seemed to improve his directing. It's such a beautifully shot and edited movie you can't help but keep your eyes off it. What a phenomenal movie in every way! I don't know how they'll top this one.

review: One of the best directed action movies in recent years, certainly one of the best in this decade. Usually, sequels get worse and worse. Mission Impossible is the one of few movies I can think of that gets better and better with each part. It's almost unbelievable that the sixth sequel to any franchise looks this good and fresh. Interestingly, the director changed for each film in the series and this film is the first where the director team remained the same. The last three are very good, and this one is probably the best in terms of quality. An interesting story that requires attention, tense action scenes that are at the highest level. I must also mention Tom Cruise who is a masterful actor as well as an action star who participates in various stunts. Shooting, driving, racing, jumping, parkour, flying, the character did absolutely everything in a very tense film through his 140 minutes, which is not a small amount for an action film. one of the most appreciated things about Cruise is that what he does onscreen is real. He really does those leaps between buildings. (He broke his ankle on one of those leaps and shut down production for seven weeks.) He really does drive a motorcycle at high speeds against traffic. He really does fly a helicopter. Who knows what motivates this guy, but the results are incredible. The music, the stunts, the actors, the cities, and the landscapes. Everything was put together amazingly well. And an ending scene that you will never forget. And, some people may find the plot quite complicated, and it is. You really need to pay attention. I recommend watching MI5, and, if you have time, all the others. There is a reference to all of them along with the movie.

review: 2012 is enjoyable trash that I've watched dozens of times. It's laughable at times, yet thoroughly enjoyable if you don't take it seriously. It's a mix of a really interesting premise with a mess of completely unrealistic actions scenes and subpar acting. The first 30-45 minutes are actually pretty engaging. I really enjoyed the buildup and the scientific findings. Then, it just turns into a comedy fest with a father protecting his family from near-death every five minutes. I mean, if this were to have been even the slightest bit realistic, it probably would've been regarded as a great end of the world flick. Instead, the directors chose to go with the typical Hollywood approach of over-glorifying chaotic action with no regard for plot/writing. However, said actions scenes are highly entertaining in my opinion and the ending gives you the payoff of a "warm, fuzzy climax", while also completely unrealistic. I regularly throw this movie on to watch in the background when I want to mindlessly watch something and for that reason alone, it's worth a watch. If you're expecting to find Oscar winning-worth performances, with a brilliant cast and writing, this probably isn't the movie for you.

review: This movie has plenty of problems, but the special effects and hyperactive plot is enough to keep anyone watching. And I'll admit, I still come back to this movie to re-watch when I want to pass some time and satisfy disaster movie cravings. 2012 has a disaster for almost everyone. You want volcanic eruptions? Check. How about megatsunamis? It's all there. I feel like that plays a big role in why I still enjoy coming back to the movie despite it not having much of anything else going for it. I'm a sucker for disaster movies. The special effects are quite spectacular. I would even say almost too over-the-top at times. But it's certainly enough to keep anyone from turning the movie off immediately. It also helps to distract from a not so great plot, which is riddled with plenty of cliches that are all too familiar in the genre. I am a scientist, and so I'm always analyzing the science behind these movies. Of course, it's science-fiction though, so it's not exactly going to hit it right on the head. I would just love to see more movies out there that are less "fiction-y" and more realistic. On the flip side of the coin, while the events that transpire in the movie stem from a fictional concept, I applaud the writers for coming up with something that's not horribly derivative. Can't say I've seen a disaster flick where the end of the world is caused by neutrinos heating up the Earth's core! Everything thing else... though, is more derivative and highly predictable. I feel like some of the conflicts in the plot are a bit overdone, cliche, or otherwise unnecessary. Nonetheless, it's a disaster flick that I won't stop watching anytime soon!
rt_name: 2012 - Movie Reviews

review: I almost feel bad giving three stars to a movie that cost $200 million. On the other hand, it grossed $769 million worldwide, so that makes me feel a little better. I tried to watch this movie a few years ago. I turned it off about halfway through, just because I was weary of the CGI special effects. They're so much like watching a cartoon. This is, without doubt, the most over the top disaster film ever made. The entire city of Los Angeles slides into the ocean, Washington D.C is obliterated, and I've lost count of the other cataclysms, but there are dozens of them. As to the characters, there is a family with young kids (there always is), the U.S president, brilliant scientists (of course), and thousands of extras, most of whom get pummeled to smithereens by toppling skyscrapers or tsunamis or exploding volcanos. Oh yeah, a giant cruise ship gets decimated by a tsunami. I liked that. I've always hated cruise ships. This movie will certainly give you your money's worth. But it's basically a 2 1/2 hour cartoon. Not a funny one, either. And there's obviously no point in raising the issue of plausibility. Cartoon's aren't supposed to be plausible.
rt_name: 2012 - Movie Reviews

review: Roland Emmerich delivers an apocalyptic adventure to viewers in this intense, explosive catastrophe. The film makes use of various world-ending prophecies, including the Mayan calendar to rip cities in half and crumble monuments to the ground. '2012' follows various characters across the globe as they race to save whatever's left of humanity. The film opens in India, where Dr Adrian Helmsley is called to the world's deepest copper mine, only to discover the Earth's crust is heating up quicker than expected and must rush back to the United States and present this information to the President (Danny Glover). On the other side of the country, in sunny Los Angeles, is failed author and limousine driver, Jackson Curtis. While camping with his kids, Jackson meets Charlie Frost (Woody Harrelson), a man who preaches that the end is near. What happens next leads Jackson and his family on a globe-trotting adventure to China for a shot at survival. As Jackson makes his way across the globe, Government officials Chiwetel Ejiofor and Oliver Platt try to save what they can, all the while trying to maintain law and order. Despite '2012' being a high-octane action film, Emmerich still manages to display emotion. Final phone calls to loved ones provide a sense of closure to some characters, while for others, it fills them with sorrow and guilt. The 158-minute runtime can't help but drag on, and there's a few unnecessary scenes and lines of dialogue that could've been skipped. The visual effects throughout the film are incredible, even with a few issues here and there. They're extremely detailed and do a great job of getting across just how much damage has occurred all around these characters. Co-writers Harald Kloser and Thomas Wander provide '2012' with a decent score that compliments the chaotic atmosphere of what's going on on-screen. Chiwetel Ejiofor gives a great performance as Dr Adrian Helmsley, starring opposite Oliver Platt, who gives an acerbic performance as Carl Anheuser. Glover shares a heart-wrenching scene in the White House chapel with Ejiofor, where he says 'I'll be the last President of the United States of America, do you know how that feels?' A quote like that makes viewers realise the magnitude of what's happening. John Cusack gives a superb performance as Jackson Curtis, a divorced father of two who just wants to maintain a good rapport with his kids. Oh, and if you recognise the name Jackson Curtis, that's because the character is named after the rapper 50 Cent. Emmerich was a big fan of the rapper and wanted to name his lead character after him. Something that Emmerich did well with '2012' is he gave viewers two different points of view. One from the more public, working-class side and the other from the up-high, government officials. That's something that not many action films do. Despite the film mentioning the Mayan calendar and culture, the Mayans didn't actually say that the world would end in 2012. Unless you include the end of the world, the main theme throughout '2012' would be family. Jackson Curtis tries to save his family and Adrian Helmsley gets to say goodbye to his father. Tony Delgatto (played by the late George Segal) tries to reconcile with his estranged son before being abruptly cut off. The film provokes the idea that your wealth and/or job can determine your survival, and when in extreme situations, people are willing to put a price on life, ‚Ç¨1 billion per person to be exact. There were production plans for a TV sequel titled '2013', but it was cancelled due to budgetary reasons. In conclusion, '2012' is a chaotic catastrophe with fiery scenery and heart-warming familial moments. The film features good performances from the entire cast and keeps an equal focus on both the ends of the world, and the people who are desperate to survive.

review: With hideous CGI, an all too familiar story, and just uninteresting new additions to the Indiana Jones saga, "Kingdom of the Crystal Skull" is a significant downgrade compared to the others. Overused CGI bogs this film down the most, though the ridiculous plot about aliens in a Mayan temple also brings the movie down significantly. The villain is also not that interesting, and the entire story doesn't feel very original, riddled with plot clich√©s and conveniences throughout. About the only good things in this film are the action and the humor, which I think still lands. Where this movie is strongest is when it strays from the whole "alien" main plot. In the end, while I enjoyed some of this film, it just isn't nearly as good when compared to the others.

review: I feel really sorry for all of those for whom this one dind't cut it. I DO understand the points they make. Neither did I fully enjoy the maya-alien plot nor every action scene in this. Shia was miscast and his performance didn't help in the slightest to make up for that. It's not a bad performance, but he's all over the map. The material he had to work with was not strong to begin with, however. Indiana Jones was something, a David Koepp script couldn't fix. The CGI gets a lot of flac for a couple of mild blunders (compared to actually bad CGI), but really isn't that bad. The departure in the end is pretty amazing. Overall this doesn't compare to its 3 predecessors. Yet, I keep revisting this movie because watching Spielberg fail is still way more entertaining than watching other directors peak. There is still much to love about this. It is by far one of the best adventure movies of the 2000s. If it had been an off brand adventure flick, people would hold it in high regards. Yet, under the weight of an Indiana Jones film, the standards are higher.

review: I watched a long time ago and I had a conflict about this film, I couldn't understand why Spider-Man 2 was considered one of the best superhero movie ever. I'll be honest, I was a kid and I didn't process the film like this days, that doesn't mean that the film didn't like in that moment. Now days, I get on the train to swear that Spider-Man 2 is the best Marvel film ever. It's an amazing mix of genre which has you on the edge of your sit during all the film. It'll thrill you, it'll make you sad, it'll amuse you, it'll make you jump out of your seat in excitement. It could be said that I am exaggerating but this film is perfect in every single aspect, the script, directing, cinematography, visual effects, the performances, editing, sound and soundtrack, achieving an unique style to be the benchmark talking about Spider-Man. It squeezes all your feelings while with a gorgeous eloquence speaks us about the importance of kindness above all. It could be summarized with great tenderness with the next verse. "I believe there's a hero in all of us, that keeps us honest, gives us strength, makes us noble and finally allows us to die with pride. Even though sometimes we have to be steady and give up the thing that we want the most. Even our dreams "

review: An improvement to the original one, "Spiderman 2" brings yet another memorable villain, with an emotional and compelling story and great action while still continuing the story perfectly from the previous installment. The acting is still perfect, and the expanding of the universe is done very well. Much like the original, the CGI still feels a bit outdated to today's standards, though it was decent enough for its time. The plot and story is arguably better, and the villain is about as well done as Green Goblin, if not better in some ways. In the end, I really loved this film, and I think it stands as one of, if not the absolute best, "Spiderman" film ever made.

review: Wow, so much better than the first one! Not a masterpiece but just a hell of a lot more fun. The first 30 minutes of the movie are an absolute blast, with real humor that lets Tobey Maguire take himself a little less seriously for a while. It starts dragging a little bit as the plot picks up, strangely, but it's got bright spots here and there until the end. Alfred Molina is all around pleasant as Doc Ock, although he comes off as a little cartoonish at times. J K Simmons is amazing as always, and I appreciated the Bruce Campbell cameo. Kristen Dunst is still passable as best, although her one-dimensional, male-dominated dialogue doesn't help. Tobey Maguire still can't make facial expressions. This movie tries to introduce some interesting ideas about mental health, responsibility, and self-care, but doesn't really develop them into anything more than "Spider-Man kicks ass whenever the plot needs him to." Peter has a bit of character development, but he tries his darndest to avoid it until circumstances force it on him. The ending is somewhat satisfying but overly cheesy for my taste. With vastly improved visuals, comedy, and characters, Spider-Man 2 is flawed but still miles ahead of its predecessor.

review: It's nice when a niche movie is confident to wear its own identity loud and proud, and this was one of the main reasons why so many, myself included, loved the Sam Raimi Spiderman film from 2001. It doesn't hurt that the film was a solid bit of what I like to call Uplifting Blockbuster entertainment, but Spiderman 2 keeps what worked with the first and adds depth and greater dimension. The villain has gone from a Charismatic Evil Baddie to a Charismatic Morally-Conflicted Baddie, the evolution of Peter and his friend Harry feels logical and realistically painful, the relationship between Peter and MJ is genuinely sweet, and even Aunt May is given a lot more time to showcase her character, and her inner strength, and her scenes with Peter about his confession to her are a serious emotional gut-punch, flawlessly and organically fused with what is otherwise a feel-good superhero action flick. Let's also throw in the fact that the CGI is a massive step-up, particularly in regards to the character animation, the action scenes are notably more intricately designed and the setpieces are actually more inventive and climactic. There's also a Transition involving sunglasses that might be my favorite Transition of any movie (or anywhere outside of some used in Sherlock). This is filmmaking at its most confident and free-flowing, and Sam Raimi is one of the best quirky filmmakers of all time, effortlessly fusing a unique and offbeat sense of fun with a big-budget adventure movie for mass audiences. If you like the genre, and don't need it to be ultra dark and pensive (the latter of which this movie sometimes is, mind you), then this is an absolute must-see, along with the first.
rt_name: Spider-Man 2 - Movie Reviews

review: Considered as one of the best superhero films of all time and winner of the Best Visual Effects Oscar in 2005, this second installment in the Sam Raimi's Spider-Man trilogy follows Peter Parker, now dissatisfied with life when he loses his job, the love of his life, Mary Jane, and his powers. And amid all the chaos, he must fight Doctor Octavius who threatens to destroy New York City. This movie's villain has a strong character development from beginning to end in its depiction as a conflicted antihero and now is one of the best superhero villains ever, a portrayal Alfred Molina should always feel proud of. The action sequences are great and the plot is captivating, with the train scene being one of the most memorable Spidey moments ever.

review: It's unanimous that Spider-Man 2 is better than its predecessor. The villain is better, Dr. Octopus is as imposing as Green Goblin and I could take him seriously, there are genuinely heart-touching moments that were almost absent in the first film, and the final 50 minutes are a spectacle. But the other side of the movie, Peter Parker's personal drama, is, like in the first film, hard to watch. Tobey and Kirsten still don't have chemistry, and consequently, the romance arc is, again, dragged (I missed Dr. Octopus during a moment). And Tobey Maguire, despite everything, is not a good actor, it's hard to empathize with him. Aunt May (looks more like grandma May) and J.K. Simmons are even better, and the newspaper boss is even funnier.

review: Not quite as tight or engaging as the previous one, but it still delivers the wild car antics and solid special effects audiences are looking for. Although stuffed with retcons, it was nice to see Letty return to the group. The physics throughout this entire movie are completely ridiculous, even more so than the previous entries, but everything moves fast enough that it's easy to overlook. The plot is pretty thin and a little full of cliches for me, especially the villain, with a vaguely world-domination-sounding plan that never gets fully explored. But again, that's not why we're here. The cars were fast and the stunts were exciting, and that's all that really matters.

review: There was a lot to like in this movie, that's for sure. I very much appreciate how they've developed characters in a way that any interaction between two of them feels like fanservice. I didn't think I'd appreciate the addition of The Rock as much as I ended up liking him and while I love the previous composer, I loved the addition of the grungey rock segments in the film score. The prison fight scene with Brian pulled me out of the movie as it was too obvious that they had sped up the framrate to make the movements appear faster and more violent than they were and throughout the movie the choreography involved fight moves clearly pulled right out of WWE, like the dropkick/elbow drop combo and the chokeslam and the freaking diving headbutt of all things that took away from the realism in a way that I disliked. I also thought it was absolutely implausible that The Rock's character would agree to let the bad guy go after chasing him for so long when it literally meant endangering millions of people all for one person as that's a stupid character arc and an objectively poor decision. He should've just shot the dude right away before he could call the kidnapper since that's pretty much how they prevented Mia's death anyway, jamming his phone. And the bad guy's radical switch from calculated smart guy to bloodthirsty dumb guy was poorly written. The action scenes were probably the best of the series so far though, and it was an enjoyable viewing experience overall.

review: It is not very common for highly successful superhero movies that explore a new genre have an equally successful sequel. Superman and Superman II, Iron Man and Iron Man 2, Man of Steel and Batman v Superman, there are plenty of examples where a great movie is followed by a mediocre or even a bad sequel. But this one is definitely not one of them. Rather I like Deadpool 2 more than its prequel. Since the previous movie was more set up in order to give an origin story and have the regular good guy vs bad guy fight, it did not have much time to explore over its humour. And this is exactly where Deadpool 2 does the job. The story revolves around Wade Wilson once again with his popping over his wife's death by a bunch of mercenaries and alongside that he is trying to save a boy from becoming a supervillain and getting killed by Cable. This movie it takes itself very lightly just like the prequel and breaks the fourth wall continuously as the story passes by. There is even a joke on Josh Brolin playing the role of cable as Deadpool says, "Suck it, Thanos!". Multiple comic scenes take place throughout the movie e which include the formation of the X-Force, Deadpool being made an X-Men trainee and no one taking him seriously, Wade Wilson been sent to prison, Deadpool fighting Cable and releasing all the mutants only to be ripped in half by Juggernaut and Deadpool growing out as a baby from the bottom half. The action scenes of this movie are even better than the previous one. I really like the scene from the beginning of the movie where Deadpool is fighting a bunch of Yakuzas in Osaka. The camera revolves around Deadpool as he slices down all the man who have come to save the leader. When juggernaut and colossus are about to fight Deadpool says, "Big CGI fight coming up!". When he is about to fight cable for the first time, Cable ask him who he is to which he replies, "I am Batman!". Overall there are multiple action comedy scenes sprinkled all across the movie. The movie also gives an important message, which is not something we normally see in an X-Men movie. Deadpool tells Russell to let the headmaster live, as killing him would send him on the path of villainy from which it will be impossible to come back. Instead of Russell Deadpool chooses to take the bullet from Cable and his death becomes the reason why Russell chooses to give up killing and become a good person instead. This also saves Cable's family from dying and he can go back in peace. But soon afterwards that message is discarded after the headmaster is run over by Dopinder's taxi, thus fulfilling his dream of becoming a contract killer. Deadpool 2, being the movie for a mature audience as it is, is hard to think of home to watch with, considering such a movie cannot be watched with the family and friends have watched it anyway. This is the reason why it's a good thing they decided to make a sequel of this movie and connect it to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. If Dark Phoenix and The New Mutants were not made, this could have been the most perfect way to culminate the X-Men franchise and merge it with the remaining Marvel Cinematic Universe. I can't wait to watch more of this.

review: Deadpool shows the power of a well-written screenplay, which is fast, sharp, incredibly funny and immensely self-aware without ever staying in the dreaded "meta" zone for more than a few seconds at a time (like Deadpool mocking Ryan Reynolds as only being successful because he's good looking). The main hero has a woefully cynical worldview, but he is actually extremely observant, and isn't just cynical due to viewing the world via an emotional skew - there is bad in the world, from the little injustices that everybody simply lets go, to the uneven value placed on human lives based on the circumstances, and his dark jokes about these things actually feel like a raunchier version of something George Carlin might have come up with. And on that note, yes - This movie is overpoweringly raunchy, so if this is not something you enjoy, then you have no business being here. Luckily, the movie has a lot more than just comedy to offer. It features a surprisingly somber story of a mildly deformed man running away from the eyes of the one he loves, which is actually quite touching. And along with that, the movie has a fair amount of action and some moments of genuine intensity, and both of these aspects are very well done; while Tim Miller might have made the most Poorly-Directed Terminator movie with Dark Fate, his Directing of Deadpool is absolutely spot-on, nailing the humor, heart and adrenaline almost flawlessly. It's not a perfect movie, but mostly because its unique and extreme style of humor, much of it winking to the camera, is so consistent that it does eventually get slightly tiresome - it's like listening to 3 Weird-Al albums back-to-back; it's always funny, but the humor is so consistent that it just wears off after a while. But if ultra-dark and raunchy humor work for you, as does some surprisingly brutal violence, then I cannot recommend Deadpool enough. I absolutely loved it and plan on watching it numerous times moving forward.

review_date: A fantastic sci-fi, fantasy movie Star Wars is certainly one of the easiest movies in the genre to digest. This may be due to its simple and straightforward plot, easily defined lines between good and evil, with characters that you want to root for. A total cotton candy movie but that's still one very enjoyable carnival treat. The only ding I have to give is the dated look of some of the sequences especially the final action scene. A lot has been said about this movie so I'll leave it at this: watch this movie if for no other reason than to see what all the fuss is about. You'll at least appreciate the Star Wars culture and you may become a fan yourself.

review: A unique and influential film that still continues to affect the world today, "A New Hope" remains one of the strongest "Star Wars" films to this day, providing insanely iconic scenes, lines, and characters that many people who haven't even seen the movie can recognize. The acting is done very well, and the worldbuilding is one of the best. This film also perfectly sets up the rest of the saga, introducing new characters and places while still leaving room for tons more to be added. The story and plot does begin to slow down after the second act finished, though it quickly picks up again during the attack on the Death Star. Overall, just a great film that continues to remain a timeless classic.

review: George Lucas isn't quite the most creative person in the history of Hollywood, but he was creative in the exact right way at the exact right time, inventing not only a unique fusion of genres (that proved way more successful than even he could have imagined) but a new type of special effects approach (moving the camera around an object, rather than the opposite like everyone else). The original Star Wars represents the pinnacle of a simple story with a hidden depth when examined closer. The world is well realized, the villains incredibly intimidating and memorable, what is and is-not possible is well established quickly, and it largely plays out as a feel-good movie with a few moments of genuine tension or drama. Mix in good performances, likable characters, awesome action sequences and some of the best audio (both music and sound effects) of any movie, and you've got a movie that has, and will forever, stand the test of time.

review: [‚≠êÔ∏è96%] Instantly viewers fell in love with the Star Wars universe thanks to A New Hope's (1977) fantastic immediate world building, all done in a natural way thanks to a great plot which takes the characters to necessary places for events to play out. All of the development for the Galaxy, force and many other aspects is done in a very efficient way which allows the viewer to be excited for an expanding galaxy and hence why the franchise still runs over 40 years after this film. Given the year it was made, 1997, this movie has some very impressive special effects, better than some you see nowadays in 2021. Despite limited screen time, Darth Vader immediately established himself as a legendary villain thanks to his menacing presence and his ability to steal every scene he is in. You couldn't ask for a better introduction to one of the most influential franchises of all time.

review: A legendary ambitious start to the ever-expanding star wars saga, George Lucas opened our eyes to new possibilities of blockbuster filmmaking and things have never been the same since audiences have seen that opening crawl for the first time. Starting in the middle of the story(Episode IV) It is a thrilling adventure of young farmboy Luke Skywalker who with the help of old Jedi master obi-wan Kenobi follows his hero's journey and begins learning the ways of the force and become a Jedi himself as he and hotshot smuggler Han solo along with wookie Chewbacca(captain and co-pilot of the Millennium Falcon), work together with the companionable droid duo of R2-D2 and C-3PO to rescue princess leia, and help the Rebel Alliance in their fight to restore freedom and justice to the Galaxy as they go up against menacing Darth Vader and his waves of imperial storm troopers. The story is a perfect morality tale as good goes up against evil and it feeds people's hunger for adventure, thrills ,and comedy. This 1977 film is a classic and with the story, John William's brilliant musical scores and the huge leaps that it takes with special effects and other filmmaking techniques(which were many building blocks towards even better techniques for modern filmmaking) this film will live on in people's hearts and minds for generations but don't take my word for it, go out there and see it for yourself!!! no longer will you have to fear about not knowing what the force is or what a wookie is or even how many languages C-3P0 can speak, this film is the perfect first steps into a larger world! May the force be with you,Always!
mojo_name: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope
rt_name: Star Wars: Episode IV -- A New Hope - Movie Reviews

review: Some kind of movie magic happened when Star Wars was made. From the reported chaos of its production, somehow everything fell into place by the time the final film was released: the perfect cast, groundbreaking special effects, amazing sound effects, great editing, an awesome music score and a fantastic adventure story with not one, but two, very different heroes taking centre stage. Star Wars has a level of realism, showing us a futuristic world where technology is fully integrated into people's daily lives, and everything has a ‚Äòused' look that made it seem very real. The iconic opening shot, with an absurdly massive Star Destroyer crawling across the screen in chase of some hopelessly outgunned little space ship, informed us that this was a world unlike any we had seen before - a place far, far away and in another time, just as the opening credits had promised. The central robot characters R2D2 and C-3PO were both believable and likeable. It was an inspired choice to have only one of the robot speak English, with the other one left to communicate through simple electronic beeps, leaving us searching for meaning in the robot's simple movements and head turns. Mark Hamill was perfectly cast as Luke Skywalker, the naive young farm boy who gets caught up in a galactic war with rebellious freedom fighters. Hamill's boyish good looks made him very relatable to the young fan base, many of whom dreamed of being Luke Skywalker long after they had left the movie theatre. Carrie Fisher was also good as the beautiful but sassy Princess Leia, and Harrison Ford announced his arrival as the alternate hero Han Solo. The story never labours, instead moving at a solid pace as one small adventure unfolds into the next. There are moments of genuine emotional depth, such as when Luke looks out over the Tatooine landscape towards the planets dual setting suns. as if longing for the future to arrive. There is also great action and adventure as the movie progresses to it climatic battle against the awesome Death Star. Star Wars still looks fresh today, and can be enjoyed over and over again.

review: Maybe it's wrong of me to criticize the storytelling in a film when the film itself is just an adaptation of what must be a really awful book to start with. But what the hell, here goes. . Americans seem to really love their treasure hunts don't they? But believing that people centuries ago sprinkled clues throughout their work, trusting that every hidden clue would survive centuries of world events (including two world wars as it turns out) and also trusting that people centuries later would find and correctly interpret and follow those clues.... What utter horse****. . Right now it's possible that i am getting my terrible films mixed up, but i think that there are even clues that could only be found because of technology like x-rays. And there is no way anyone living 500 years ago could have predicted that tech, not even DaVinci himself. . It's laughable. And this is laughably bad. But no joke, i recently suffered from a prolonged bout of insomnia, so i rented one of this films sequels, and that cured me within an hour.

review: I always thought the best selling Dan Brown book, being a nuanced mystery thriller, would not translate well onto screen. Sadly that's the case with this average and rather underwhelming adaptation. It's not a bad film, but it doesn't live up to the hype of the book. The screenplay is okay but it's let down by poor cinematography which is perplexing when you consider all the spectacular filming locations. However, it feels like its filmed in perpetual night with most of it spent shuffling around dark, murky rooms where its actually very difficult to see whats going on. I'll give credit to a fairly uplifting ending but still very average.

review: The Da Vinci Code is overly long and stuffed with historical/religious explanations rather than meaningful dialogue. The plot was ridiculous and muddled, the characters weren't believable either, and the pacing was too slow. The acting was average at best from most of the cast, including Tom Hanks. The twist villain was silly, but I'll admit that I didn't expect it. Then I thought the ending was poor. The cinematography and visual effects were bland, and even Hans Zimmer's soundtrack wasn't as good as it is without the film. Disappointing considering I've heard good things about this film.

review: Fun action film that goes a bit too far at times but makes for a enjoyable ride. The cast is fun, with Johnson and Statham bouncing off each other nicely as Hobbes & Shaw, while Idris Elba makes a compelling bad guy. Behind the camera, director David Leitch makes some fun action scenes but doesn't quite get the emotion of the characters, delivering the family moments that make the "Fast & Furious" franchise truly work. A pity, since the ingredients are there, from Shaw & his sister to Hobbes and his estranged family, but it never quite jells. A fun watch, but a little shallow.

review: Wow. Just wow. This isn't a superhero movie or even a sci fi and is not in the same genre; people must learn what that is, instead it's more like a special effects packed action fuelled fast paced blockbuster with brilliant technology, style, money and humour. You can expect the level of nonsense nowadays more so because most of the fast and furious entries lately have been too over the top they were from the start. Now, you've the very best in action stars Jason Statham who at only five foot nine took the usual hammering in terms of a roasting from the Americans. Plus you've Dwayne who looked amazing in this until the later stages when he appeared to have lost his entire pump with the amount of work he had put in. The two characters got at one another in the same way Kevin hart does which was fun at first then became tiring. The film was at its best when it was more serious. Future tip dial down the undue excess, dial down the immature phrases and dial down the special effects and you've instead of showing off all the money most of the cities you filmed in just do not have, actually use what was best in the film, old school and charisma. Special mention for the females in this movie, the extras including the army of bad guys were very poor in this almost made this comic book like, but the female lead did her part even if she was just a spare part towards the end. Statham was bound to produce coming from some silly films such as spy and the Meg, whereas Dwayne had to pump up to de-emphasise his ageing stubble, the two looked remarkable they got on well. Jason is better when he's no nonsense serious and so is the rock with that added humour and banter. Although at times this went too far like with Ryan Reynolds to be taken as a serious movie this annoyed me. The audience compared this too much to the franchise which is just as mad, finally less irrelevance on super cars and more on actually showing us just how sensational these two men are.

review: The first two thirds of this movie are a little bit of a slog - it takes a while for the story to get going and for the cast to really have anything to work with, and most of the action up until this point has been generic and really nothing special. A lot of the CGI is obvious and awkward. But the final act in Samoa is so exciting, beautiful, and action-packed that it pretty much redeems everything we went through to get there. Dwayne Johnson finally gets his chance to shine in this installment, showcasing some solid fight choreography while also showing surprising restraint in the humorous and emotional scenes. Jason Statham also gets a lot of redemption (as does his character), making him a lot more likable in this film than in the previous F&F installments. Although it's marketed along with and takes place in the Fast & Furious universe, this film is firmly NOT a Fast & Furious film (which is ultimately for the best). For one thing, Hobbs & Shaw is almost entirely a buddy comedy film, with a good bit of action and some emotional scenes thrown in. Ryan Reynolds is funny and unexpected, although Kevin Hart's character felt altogether unnecessary. Although it's much more of a traditional action film than what we're used to in this franchise, it stands on its own pretty well and gives the leads a chance to shine apart from the bloated cast of the main series.
rt_name: Fast & Furious Presents: Hobbs & Shaw - Movie Reviews

review: The origin story of the character from Disney's Sleeping Beauty animated film done in live action starring Angelina Jolie. This film is not a live action remake of the original film, instead making the villain of the original the protagonist of her own film. Maleficent is one of my favorite villain characters of all time and I wish they would have told the original story (expanded for time) from the villain's point of view. Instead they ruin the characters of the good fairies and Maleficent herself. Angelina Jolie is perfectly cast as the title character and does a great job in the role. The scene taken from the original movie when she curses Aurora as a child was really well done. The rest of the movie is not what I wanted, nor what I needed. #notmymaleficent
rt_name: Maleficent - Movie Reviews

review: I've waited a long time for this to finally return to Disney+. Honestly, the wait wasn't worth it. Between the hype, a sequel & Jolie, I expected magnificent special effects, adventure, and an epic character study of a good-hearted-girl-turned-evil queen. It has great effects; I will give it that. But, where the film fails is in its character-arc. Rather than display Maleficent's gradual transition, the film spends a max of 4 minutes, where Jolie goes from a weepy girl having lost her wings, to a woman limping in frustration, to an villainous queen seated on a thrown of her own making (and with a pair of body guards lookin like undead versions of Groot). This is not character development. And, there is also very little to be said for the man she loves, who ultimately becomes the rival King. His portrayal falls flat, but I'd can hardly blame. The character is one dimensional with dialogue to match. And, his betrayal, with no buildup, makes about as much sense as Maleficent's turn to the darkside. Might have to skip the sequel.

review: There are people here who are disappointed that this movie has no resemblance to the animated movie from decades ago...but that is presumably the intended idea. The movie is certainly scary and violent without being gory, but definitely don't take little kids to see this one. It will be quite unsuited for them. Maleficent begins life as an immature fairy in a beautiful, harmonious fairy world next to a conventional and harsh kingdom. She is visited by Stefan, a boy of a similar age from the kingdom, who implies that someday he will live in the king's castle. An innocent romance begins, but soon ends as the boy grows older, and the current ruler of the kingdom attempts to invade the fairy world with his army to steal its treasures, only to fail. As the old king is dying, Stefan claims the throne by amputating and stealing the fairy's wings. He gets the crown, marries, and has a baby daughter...only for the now-embittered and vengeful Maleficent to arrive and place a curse on the daughter. Stefan is forced to have his daughter raised by three fairies to try to keep her safe...and in the process, becomes embittered and vengeful himself. But over the years, as the daughter grows up, unaware of what had happened, Maleficent sees her and starts having second thoughts. But the cold war has started between Maleficent and Stefan; can Maleficent undo the damage she has done? Like most characters in recent fairy tale-themed movies, nobody is entirely good or evil, and everyone is the victim of the attitudes of their respective cultures and eras. Good for teenagers or above, but too upsetting for the young kids.

review: Definitely one of the better live action remakes. Angelina Jolie is obviously incredible, the visuals and CGI are mostly impressive, I really like the score for this movie and there's some really epic and emotional moments in this movie like the action scene against the king, Maleficent cursing Aurora and the entire 3rd act. It's quite impressive and can get pretty violent for a Disney movie. But by far the biggest issue with the movie is the pacing. This movie drags on so many times during the 2nd act, especially the scenes with Aurora discovering the moors and it just isn't interesting but overall, it's a good time. I enjoy it.
rt_name: Maleficent - Movie Reviews

review: Maleficent is such a disappointing watch for a few reasons. The first 20 minutes were icky, with the child actresses not being the most expressive. The start of the movie just felt like a huge waste of time, but when Maleficent got her wings cut off by her boyfriend who went psycho on her for a really dumb reason, I thought the movie might pick itself up. It did indeed do this... for about 5 minutes. Evil Maleficent was intimidating for a few seconds and how she put a curse on the princess for revenge, but then Maleficent kind of just picked on Aurora (the princess) and then they became best friends 5 minutes later because Maleficent related to her? Then Aurora goes to her father's castle after finding out Maleficent put a curse on her. But when Aurora gets to the castle and meets her dad, the dad just goes, "L.O.L, I told those stupid fairies to deliver you the day after today." And then the king just locks the princess up with no compassion at all. The final battle was pretty lame. Maleficent just drops the king, learns some stupid moral, the end. The film's pacing is really off, wasting the first twenty minutes with bad acting and a dumb twist villain, then rushing Maleficent's redemption 10 minutes later with the movie not giving you enough room to see Aurora's personality. To top it all off, the movie ends with a rushed out ending. Don't even get me started on the side characters. Everyone here is so unlikeable. For instance, the fairies aren't as fun in this movie as they were in the original movie. These fairy's just end up not even caring for Aurora. The crow (who's the best character in this movie) does a better job of looking after Aurora than the fairy's could ever do. The king is just really angry for no rhyme or reason, yes his child was cursed, but he just shoves her to the side in the final act like I just said. Maleficent her self is just pathetic, she just ends up being soft, but since she's the good guy, she actually ends up bing pretty likeable. But since she's just a big softy now, all of her intimidation she had in the original is gone. The movie takes itself too seriously at times as well, with the closest thing too funny is when Maleficent is picking on Aurora when she was little. In conclusion, just go watch sleeping beauty.

review: I really like this film, best spider man ever in my opinion. Ok, something had to be fixed for sure (the development of Harry Osborn's character wasn't that good, for example, but if we think about the initial intention of the making of TASM 3 and 4, maybe he would have received the right development; also Electro skin wasn't good because he wasn't like the comics one, but I think that when we watch a film based on comics or books or kinda of, it will never be like the original) but the good stuff is more than the bad. review: After watching it for the first time in maybe 3 or 4 years and thinking about it. I don't think I hate Amazing Spider-Man 2 anymore! Is it convoluted? Absolutely. Is there too much in it that goes absolutely nowhere (mainly because they were questions to be answered in a conclusive chapter of a trilogy) yes maybe a little too much! Are the origins for the villains a little cheesy or bad? Maybe they weren't bad maybe it was just the execution of it because I could be wrong but I think they draw heavily from Ultimate Spider-Man comics. BUT the score is incredible, of every single Spider-Man movie we've ever had ASM2 is the absolute most gorgeous and visually stunning. No movie is this fucking cool looking. Andrew gave his performance 110% and his chemistry with everyone even someone giving as bad a performance as Dane DeHaan seems to work for the movie it is. Every actor gives everything they've got in this and you can tell, it's not like Spider-Man 3 where you can tell that almost nobody cared and because everyone's acting is so good in this the emotional moments do hit and they often hit hard!!! Honestly this to me has the best, most accurate portrayal of Peter Parker; funny and smart as hell that's not just trying to impress Mr.Stark, what he doesn't know we see him actually try to figure out without the solution being "Oh Mr.Stark put this in my suit already!" Most of my issues with this movie has always been that I hate (and still do) that a looooot of the plot is heavily solved through pure coincidence. That whole plane massacre sequence at the beginning of the movie where Richard Parker is fighting for his life to try and upload his confession video not to send it to a news station, not to send it to someone he knows will do something good like Ben or another scientist, not the police, he sends it to his private computer currently sitting in a secret laboratory under an decades abandoned subway terminal that you only have access to by inserting in these specific slightly different subway tokens that are hidden inside his calculator that Peter only found because he got mad and threw the calculator and it broke and it just so happens that the video sent was also an apology to grown up Peter. Yeah that's absolutely convoluted and even with my newfound respect and even liking for the movie thinks that whole thing should have been cut. But look at the villains, all the groundwork is there. Their stories are actually well grounded and good, it's just the performances that made them seem stupid. Max Dillon becoming Electro; he's a man whose always belittled, bullied at work by EVERYONE despite being one of the top people in his field, has no friends had to buy his own birthday cake and sing Happy Birthday to himself that when he finally gets power he can exact the revenge on those who've wronged him! That's an awesome origin story it was just the weird direction in how Jamie Fox, who I don't blame for the bad performance, director Mark Webb other than Amazing Spider-Man had only done indie romcoms. And even with the weird writing and directing Jamie Fox gave it his all. Harry Osborne his mom died and his dad never cared about him, sent him away when he was really you and rarely if ever saw him or thought about him again. The first time he sees his father in years he's on his death bed saying "Hey, this disease I have. Guess what? It's genetic haha!" Then he has to learn to trust Peter because everytime he's made a friend or thought he did they only liked him for his money! And I do like that subplot of Oscorp trying to push out Harry but trying to figure out how. That too is great groundwork for the bad guy. Now this I do blame Dane DeHaan for because he's reacting to everything right but there's still just something about his performance that makes it seem cringey. Paul Giamatti gave the worst performance of his career as the rhino but hey no movie no matter how great is perfect. But the fight choreography in this is Incredible, it's not like a lot of superhero movie fight scenes where either it's too dark or the camera is too shaky and you can't see what's happening or there's a lot of weird cuts and transitions that you still can't see what's happening. This was a for a while my absolute least favorite comic book movie right up there with shit like Superman 4 and Batman Forever and Robin but being that I haven't watched this in years I do admit this is now a guilty pleasure. It's by no means simply due to the plot issues a good movie but I do enjoy the good aspects a lot more now.

rt_name: The Amazing Spider-Man 2 - Movie Reviews

review: A noticeable downgrade from the first, "The Amazing Spiderman 2" feels more like a beginning of a sequel that never happened. The entire film does not feel complete, and the ending feels rushed over. The villains, Electro especially, are all just forgettable despite the cast that is behind it. The action and humor still lands though, and Garfield and Stone continue to play their characters very well. The conclusion leaves a very sour taste in your mouth, especially when considered that there is no sequel to follow this up, which was originally planned. Overall, this is a confusing mess of a film that I really wanted to love more, though it failed to stick the landing in one too many areas.
rt_name: The Amazing Spider-Man 2 - Movie Reviews

review: I skipped The Amazing Spider-man franchise due to so much negative reviews from fans but then decided to give it a try. Actually, I liked this franchise. It was fun to watch but it looked like movie hasn't move out of first part. Showing us Peter parents fate and romance scenes more than villains scene was a bad idea. When a sequel is made, it is made using new ideas but it looked like director used maximum elements of first part due to which you can't feel fresh while watching second part. Overall, it was fun to watch but not better than part first part.

Plus, the storyline does not make sense, the main problem being: Max Dillon idolizes Spider-Man before becoming Electro but becomes a villain after becoming Electro. üôÑ And for reasons I cannot explain, the death of Gwen Stacy just wasn't moving. rt_name: The Amazing Spider-Man 2 - Movie Reviews

review: While disappointing after the first one, the second one still has a strong enough script and an amazing cast: Emma Stone, Andrew Garfield, Sally Field, Dane DeHaan, Jamie Foxx. DeHaan was an absolute standout in this movie and he completely stole the show. His portrayal of Harry Osborn is my personal favourite- he manages to make us feel pity, disgust, annoyance, and empathy, all at different points for this tortured character. I would have loved to have seen more of DeHaan's abilities and talent in the ASM franchise. *SPOILER ALERT* Marc Webb's directing is absolutely phenomenal and genius. When Aunt May reveals that Peter's father was a traitor, the camera angle tilts- Peter's work has been turned on it's side, it has become askew. Later, when Peter finds the Subway train and finds out the truth about his father and his work, the camera rights itself- Peter's world is righted.

review: WARNING: THIS REVIEW HAS SPOILERS! The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is the worst Spider-Man film until then. The cast from the first movie still does a great job, but none of the new characters works. Harry Osborn is a poor version of the emo Tobey Maguire with a bit of Draco Malfoy. The actor is terrible and his arc is badly developed and also rushed. Electro is the worst Spider-Man villain in the cinema of all time. Jamie Foxx here is as invisible as his character, who has no motivation for hating Spider-Man (Lizard also didn't have, but at least he was imposing). And the romantic arc, which was masterfully done in the first film, becomes a "To All the Boys 3" but with Noah Centineo's character being the protagonist. There's no history. The best things of this film are: it deepens on Peter's parents backstory, the chemistry between Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone still works and Gwen's death is painful and touching. Oh, and the movie should have ended in the funeral scene, and everything after it could be post-credit or middle-credit scenes.

review: Even more of a mixed bagged than its predecessor, The Amazing Spider-man 2 improves on the good parts of the original like its protagonist and the chemistry between the cast, but it butchers so much stuff. The saddest part is, it felt like director Marc Webb had a clear vision for the sequel but the studio interfered and forced him to shove another villain in at the last second. Speaking of villains, one is poorly written and just lazy, and green goblin's development is just non-existent. The pacing is god awful during the second act and every subplot feels out of place, the sinister six setup feels like Sony was just trying to make more money by teasing them and the story arc of Peter's parents (if you can even call it a story arc) has no place in the story and doesn't have a satisfying pay off. Nothing we learn about them is something that subverts our expectations, it's all old news. That being said, Peter Parker, Gwen Stacy, their relationship and Gwen's death scene are all phenomenal. It's strange seeing Marc Webb being able to deliver on arguably the most powerful death scene in any movie, and then also be the man responsible for Electro and Green Goblin. There's not much more I can say that hasn't been said yet, it's corporate pandering, it's lazily written and could've been so much more if they just focussed on one villain and expanded on the dynamic between said villain and Peter. If only there had been a The Amazing Spider-man 3, maybe that would've been the golden child of the series.

review: It's finally here! The last chapter to the popular Hunger Games movie series that broke literary sales records, made Jennifer Lawrence's career and influenced young girls everywhere to take up archery is finally coming to a close... well sort of. This is only part 1 of the final chapter. In it's infinite wisdom, Lionsgate films has decided to take the Harry Potter route in finishing off the Hunger Games series. What can I say about this movie that hasn't already been said about the second to last Harry Potter movie? Some may call this film a necessary bridge to the final chapter of the series, others may call it a gradual build to something far grander in scale than what we've seen before in other Hunger Games films. Some may say that but the fact of the matter is, this movie is just plain old fashioned filler. Trust me, I've read the books and the only thing you're seeing in this film is pure filler. I don't think I'm giving anything away by telling you that The third book of the Hunger Games saga depicts the events of a massive war between the capital and the other districts but it's not ALL just a battle, there are quite a few pieces of plot that need to occur leading up to the epic spectacle of war, things that the makers of the Hunger Games film series would rather just get out of the way than have them share the spotlight with what is sure to be the special effects event of fall 2015. I could go on and tell you about everything else in the film as far as the cast and the story and the special effects but honestly, nothing has changed since the last film. Everyone does a good job and the film ends up where it needs to be but the overarching feeling behind it all is that it all of it adds up to being just a bunch of Hollywood BS stretching out projects for no reason. There's no real reason for this movie to exist, everything that happens here could have been explained in the first 20-30 minutes for the most part, Lionsgate just decided that they wanted to line their coffers with a little more coin before this franchise ends. Eh, who can blame them. Money is money after all. Unfortunately it doesn't add up to a very entertaining ride for everyone else in the theater. All in all, if you're a fan of The Hunger Games films, you're seeing this for only one reason, to get to part 4 where the real action is. If you're just a casual fan, I'd say read the back of the DVD case or the wiki synopsis and hell, just watch the trailer and prepare yourself for part 4 because that's what you should be paying to see, not this. Perhaps I'll have a different opinion of the series once part 2 of Mocking Jay comes out, but as it stands right now on it's own, Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1 gets a 2.5...out of 5

review: I don't care what anyone says. This movie is great in so many ways, which is shocking since the actual book wasn't that good but the movie manages to stay loyal to the book whilst also being a great movie, even if it's only part 1. Every actor gives 10/10 performance, including the casting for Coin, the sets for district 13 and 8 are fabulous, I loved seeing the rebels in district 4 and 7 as well as the added scene with Snow talking to all of Panem. It makes for an intense , suspenseful political thriller that allows the viewer to take in what happens by not moving too fast. The Hanging Tree sequence is probably my favorite in the franchise, the score is remarkable and the action that is around is great. It's not perfect as it does have to adapt from a book that is just good and splitting it into two parts was a bad idea with not much action in th book but it's still a great movie.

review: A smart political drama to get teenagers involved in politics. Francis Lawrence's coming of age sci-fi political drama The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014) is an interesting installment in a franchise built on blood, then goes deeper into social dynamics and what it takes to create a revolution. Suzanne Collins' writing is interesting as she acknowledges the need for political propaganda in order to maintain order and unite the districts. Mockingjay - Part 1 sets up for the grand finale with style and class as Katniss must film President Snow's atrocities to inform and unite all people to her righteous cause. I think Lawrence finds fresh perspective on teenagers rebelling and relating to these heroes with his slick direction. I must mention that Lorde is on the soundtrack for this movie. Her astonishing dream pop anthem "Yellow Flicker Beat" calls on the youth to rebel and be themselves with frightening majesty. I love how it's the last thing you hear in the movie as the end credits start to play. Likewise, James Newton Howard's score has never been more evocative and emotional, especially towards the end of Mockingjay. I love his music for this fiery franchise. Jennifer Lawrence is incredible as empathizing with Katniss Everdeen and the struggle of an oppressed people. The Hunger Games movies mean more than entertainment, but a warning against allowing your society to crumble. We should all be rising together like Katniss in these turbulent times. Lawrence is inspiring, lovely, and haunting as the distraught and conflicted Katniss trying to do what she believes is right. Josh Hutcherson is excellent as the captured Peeta Mellark, painfully tortured and forced to deliver half-hearted messages to the Mockingjay revolution. Liam Hemsworth is interesting as the conflicted Gale Hawthorne, who wants to be there for the already spoken for Katniss, while fighting alongside his people. Woody Harrelson is outstanding as the heartfelt Haymitch Abernathy, standing alongside Katniss through it all. Elizabeth Banks is increasingly emotional as the entertaining eccentric Effie Trinket. Julianne Moore is fantastic as the cold and calculating President Alma Coin. She bears a knowing confidence I find revealing. Rest in paradise to the ever amazing Philip Seymour Hoffman as the crafty architect of the Mockingjay revolution Plutarch Heavensbee. Jeffrey Wright is more clever and cunning than ever as the technical genius Beetee. Stanley Tucci is more underhanded as the propaganda announcer Caesar Flickerman. Donald Sutherland is more vindictive and vicious than ever as President Snow. His calm fury is fascinating to watch unfold on the masses. Willow Shields is very emotive as Primrose Everdeen with her hurt looks and helpful healing practices as a revolutionary nurse. Sam Claflin was awesome in Catching Fire and he's captivating with his dark dramatic performance as Finnick Odair. Jena Malone gets a memorable cameo as Johanna Mason. I wish she were in more of Mockingjay. Mahershala Ali is cool as Katniss' new protector Boggs. Natalie Dormer is cool and gorgeous as the propaganda director Cressida. Ve Neill's make-up for Dormer is so wonderful with her green tattoos and undercut hairstyle. The costumes in Mockingjay are all wicked armor with plenty to love. Philip Messina's harsh industrial production design is striking like Jo Willems' vivid cinematography. I love his wide shot of Katniss shooting down two jets with her bow. The close-up of Jennifer Lawrence's face to the jets is killer. Lastly, Alan Edward Bell and Mark Yoshikawa's snappy editing makes Mockingjay's 123 minutes fly by like the bird. In all, Mockingjay is not as phenomenal as The Hunger Games or Catching Fire, but it inspires a sense of anarchy and rebellion in you for sure.
rt_name: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay, Part 1 - Movie Reviews

review: Once you grow up and realize the realities of conflict, inner turmoil and the fight to do what's right, you hopefully lose any immature attachments to fleeting fancies of the heart. Sadly, this film doesn't recognize that. Collins wrote these books for a YA audience but the stakes within the plot are so high that the naive YA heart tugs are a fatal error. Katniss and Peeta's love story arc was never fully developed in the first place , so for her to be so hung up on Peters fate that it causes her to play the reluctant hero role is outright silly. There are scenes early on in this film where Katniss is screaming and crying over poor Peters fate that is supposed to make us feel for her quest for love, instead it's just a childish distraction. Had she stepped into the hero role and been mature enough to know that none of her allies had any choice in the impending revolution, thus meaning Peeta no harm, it would have been such a stronger and more well defined study in the rise of the Mockingjay. It's like you're watching a 14 year old Tiger Beat mellowdrama play out for no good reason. All that aside, the dystopian vision of censorship, power and mind control from within governmental systems is well thought out and worth the trip down the rabbit hole. The heroines conviction for the cause does bloom eventually, thank God. Otherwise, this film would be a waste of time.

review: Muy buena pel√≠cula, sin duda un digno final y definitivamente el mejor ejemplo de una obra infravalorada. Es una pena lo poco apreciada que est√° esta pel√≠cula. Creo que fue el resultado de la tercera entrega, y el mal sabor que dej√≥ la franquicia. Al volver a ver la pel√≠cula, me sirvieron mucho los temas maduros que toca y su profundidad en los personajes. Uno de mis aspectos favoritos de la pel√≠cula, es el antagonista 'Rumpelstiltskin', quiz√°s no es el mejor (ya que para mi sigue siendo el hada madrina) pero es muy memorable. Por otro lado, me gustaron mucho todas las escenas emocionantes que te dejan al borde del llanto, o llorando directamente. Esto hace que no sea tan divertida como las dos primeras pel√≠culas, pero me gusta por donde llevaron esta pel√≠cula, d√°ndole un toque diferente. Por otro lado, la pel√≠cula no iguala a la primera ni obviamente a la segunda, pero por lo menos es un digno final de la franquicia y no es olvidable para nada. Tambi√©n me gust√≥ mucho el soundtrack de la pel√≠cula y la animaci√≥n es genial, se nota una gran evoluci√≥n en cuanto a las anteriores y que se gasto mucho mas presupuesto esta vez. Destaco mucho tambi√©n el doblaje latino que sigue siendo muy bueno. Por √∫ltimo, el final es muy satisfactorio, dejando un mensaje hermoso y un montaje musical con la misma canci√≥n del final de la primera pel√≠cula; concluyendo con los cr√©ditos mostrando escenas ic√≥nicas de toda la saga, simplemente hermoso. En conclusi√≥n, una pel√≠cula incomprendida con un final muy digno que se mantiene fresca gracias a las hermosas animaciones, el gran desarrollo de Shrek y una buena historia. Muy recomendada.

review: This review contains spoilers. I honestly don't understand all this hatred of the movie. I didn't grow up with the Shrek saga: during the lockdown I saw all 4 films in order. And for someone who saw the film for the first time, I found it a great product. The animations are a big improvement over the previous 3 films and the characters are beautiful to look at. The story is very controversial, but I found it to be in full swing with the franchise, because let's be honest: Shrek never really changed his temper. It certainly hasn't stayed where it started, but evolution is minimal. Here, finally, he manages to have a real evolution in line with the character. In my opinion, Shrek has not undergone a regression, but only a wave of nostalgia that blinded him. The idea of going back is what the franchise needed: going too far was a huge risk. So, instead, they eliminated the damage of a third sequel. The remaining characters are well adapted to the other reality and donkey always remains the best. The villain, the focus of the film, has a very good characterization and his plan is very well done. On one issue, however, I can agree: it is less parody and more serious. But that's exactly what the franchise needed as an ending (for now). With the fourth film, the franchise doesn't lose the whammy, it stays fresh thanks to the beautiful animations, great development of Shrek and a good story. An underrated masterpiece.

review: This triquel to the Madagascar franchise is better and worse than the first two movies. The film once again keeps the same flaws with the poor pacing, the lack of character development, the hit-or-miss jokes thrown out of nowhere, and the message it tries to tell. However the movie does have more charm and better animation quality. There is one scene that nearly blew me way visually at the circus when Alex, Marty, Gloria, Melman, and the rest have their final performance. And the characters do have a side romance plot which does feel like something pushing the story a bit more forward. But that's basically it like I've said before.

review: Oh, dear. One of the more traumatic incidents of my teenage life was my friend's mother blaring that horrendous will.i.am song on a two-hour car journey. Admittedly, this still dwells in my mind and this rating might not be fair. I just found myself gritting my teeth far more than laughing. Maybe I need to brighten up. Look at that cast. The additions alone are star-studded. Frances McDormand playing a villainous Frenchwoman? Bryan Cranston playing a Russian tiger? Jessica Chastain playing a jaguar? Gold waiting to be found, but their accents were distractingly below par, especially in McDormand's case. Sacha Baron Cohen as a lemur having a whirlwind romance with a bear voiced by Frank Welker of Scooby-Doo fame might have looked good on paper, but reeked of unoriginality and never once provoked so much as a smile. Imagine my surprise when I saw that Noah Baumbach wrote the script. Not exactly what he seems to be known for. There are a few good jokes, make no mistake, but the entire affair seems like a half-baked, scattershot cash-in upon guaranteed success. The story follows every necessary and unnecessary indulgence and contrivance in the book. For that reason, I simply could not enjoy it.

review_date: I only have vague memories of watching the first Madagascar movie with some friends and their kids. At the time I thought it was kind of cute, but mostly forgettable. I certainly didn‚Äôt think it was going to spawn an entire franchise of films and TV shows, but to my surprise it did. One of the sequels was Madagascar 3: Europe‚Äôs Most Wanted. And, for the record, I did indeed watch this without seeing the 2nd movie in the franchise. I don‚Äôt think much context was needed because this movie is its own insane thing. My distant memories of the first Madagascar film told me that it was all about them wanting to escape captivity to live in the wild. As a result, I found it quite odd that the entire plotline of Madagascar 3 was structured around the heroes wanting to return to their cages. I guess they felt they had a level of fame in the zoo, and they wanted to be loved and adored by humans again. In order to earn their way back to the US they decide to join the circus. There they meet some new friends that love them and accept them as part of the act. From that point on, I‚Äôm sure you can write the rest of the plot for them. It‚Äôs not an original story, and I found it rather boring. There‚Äôs been a trend in many animated films lately to include fast-paced insanity instead of story or actual comedy. This annoys me tremendously, and gets me cringing rather than laughing. Madagascar 3 is a poster child for this film-making style. Everything is moving at a mile a minute, and we‚Äôre asked to laugh just because it‚Äôs weird. I cannot even recall a single joke that worked in the film, and the story was utter nonsense. As one small example of the stupidity of this movie, somehow the animals all make it from Madagascar to Monte Carlo (I guess by swimming there.) Yet they must go through the entire plot of joining the circus, and working to make it successful enough to tour in New York, in order to make it back home. I understand the real goal of the film-makers was to get the animals in a new and interesting situation, but they couldn‚Äôt even invent a decent way of getting them there. I was so detached and disinterested throughout this entire film, despite the fact that it has some decent voice talent. Sadly, they were all performing their voices in an exaggerated fashion, so it was rather obnoxious. There were times when I was actively trying to ignore Madagascar 3, so that I wouldn‚Äôt be annoyed by its frenetic idiocy. Maybe this stuff works for kids, but for me it was tedious, to say the least.

review: Hell to Pay has its problems such as Harley Quinn feeling pointlessly shoehorned in, an excessive cast of characters despite the short runtime and a somewhat convoluted explanation behind an otherwise really good plot twist but the Suicide Squad's third film outing following Assault on Arkham and the 2016 film is still tons of fun. Not to the same level as the kickass James Gunn film I saw two weeks ago but it's another good showing of why DC continues to remain virtually unchallenged when it comes to the direct-to-DVD market. The voice acting is great as always, the action sequences are thrilling, the plot, while generic, fits Task Force X better than the generic doomsday villain of the live-action film, there are good dynamics between some of the characters, the quips put a smile on my face and last but not least, the movie actually tries its damnedest to justify its R-rating unlike The Killing Joke and Justice League Dark, which were honestly less violent than the crazy stuff shown to us in Flashpoint Paradox. Thank God I'm not squeamish to these kinds of things, otherwise I'd have come out of cinema showing of the equally bloody, if not gorier, 2021 film a gibbering, nervous wreck. While slightly inferior to Assault on Arkham, Hell to Pay still succeeds in doing what the 2016 film failed to do, give the Suicide Squad the film adaptation they truly deserve that truly embraces its source material's "no-punches-pulled" nature.
rt_name: Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay - Movie Reviews

review: Before I begin to review this movie I would like to take a moment to tell how much I lived under a rock when it came to superhero stuff. So as a kid I never liked superhero cartoons. I always found them over the top. So I had no idea whatsoever about superhero stuff. I thought Batman is just like Superman except he wears a mask, Superman is weak af because I always used to see him get beaten up every time I skimmed through the cartoon channels and saw a glimpse of Justice League or Superman. And the best part - I didn't even know what DC was. I used to think all the superheroes are made by Marvel. So when Suicide Squad was announced in 2016, our teacher had asked us which movie we want to watch. I had said Rustom (a Bollywood film) while the rest of the class said Suicide Squad. I had seen posters of Suicide Squad and I used to think it's just some mindless action film like all zombie movies. So my friend told me it's gonna have Joker in it. I combines two and two together and understood that Suicide Squad is a DC movie. And no, my stoogeness is still not over (wait for it): I was now excited for the movie, because I thought Joker will be played by Heath Ledger! So of course, then we know what all happened. The movie was bad, everyone lost hopes from DCEU, yada yada. But anyway, why I brought this story up is because my very first introduction to Suicide Squad was by the 2016 movie, and that's surely not a good way to be introduced. Sure I understood the concepts, but I had no respect left for the franchise. It's like learning about Green Lantern or Fantastic Four from their movies (...okay, I'll admit. That's how I learnt about them too). So now that I was watching DCAMU, I was a little nervous from watching this movie. But then I thought, let's just go with it. What's the worst that can happen? And surprisingly this is way better than the trashy movie. Now don't get me wrong. I'm all in for the Ayer Cut, provided it fixes that movie. But now I have already been introduced to Suicide Squad the wrong way and nothing can fix that. This is much better. Finally this was the movie that brought the Flashpoint Paradox back to relevance with the rest of the DCAMU movies, which was otherwise never talked about again. The whole Ticket to Heaven storyline was awesome. Everyone was dying at some point, so it was very thrilling to root for any one character. Although I had a hunch that Harley Quinn and Deadshot will never die since they didn't die in the movie either, yet I was really tensed for them. This is in spite of the fact that I don't like either of the two characters. But seeing them all travel in a bus and interact with each other for the first time was very nice to see. The animation, fight scenes (especially Zoom cutting down Bronze Tiger in the end), everything was so awesome. It's nice to see how much DC can do if WB does not keep meddling it. If this movie didn't exist, or rather should I say, if I had not decided to become interested in superhero stuff and not just looked at what the normies are looking at, I'd have continued to hate Suicide Squad. The Suicide Squad, Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League, the possible Ayer Cut - I'd have hated them all and not even bothered to see them. Thanks to this movie I have become a lot more accepting towards this franchise and can now watch it without the fear of getting bored.

review: If you're looking for a proper Suicide Squad film, this is a close as you're going to get (so far). Fast-paced, action-packed and violent with a dash of mature-ish humour, the tone of the film is pretty much spot-on and exactly what you'd expect (and want) from a film about a bunch of tough-to-deal-with, eccentric killers forced into a team together. It's full of interesting characters and great interactions which means you're never bored. It plays out more like an action/thriller as opposed to your typical superhero film, complete with a few unexpected twists, which is definitely a good thing. This is one for an older audience and is just a helluva fun time. Once again, it proves that Marvel may be the kings of live-action, but DC is light-years ahead when it comes to animations.
