review: Lately, DC's animated features have been a bit of a mixed bag of good and bad. "Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay" seems to suffer that same fate but in a way that still leaves the film entertaining. On the negative side, the film has some really awkward character animation and some really horrible 3-D animation. On the positive side, however, the story is great and does a killer job of connecting itself to one of DC's best animated films, the voice acting is fantastic, and the action and content is able to be exciting and dark without it feeling like it is being gratuitous in nature. Basically, it is one of those rare occasions where DC manages to deliver an R-rated feature that doesn't feel like the goal was to get an R-rating but rather tell a great story that just so happens to get an R-rating. Overall, this is a great addition to DC's animated library. Hello! My name is Rev. Ron and if you feel like checking out more of my reviews (including a more in-depth look at "Suicide Squad: Hell to Pay") you can visit my blog at RevRonMovies.BlogSpot.com. But he was so much weaker, but for a good reason. I won't spoil why. But I'm glad it shows he would've beat everyone if he was at his full strength. And even in his weak point, he still was stronger and better than anyone else. But other than him the movie is pretty meh and boring at times. The team keeps you entertained with their banter and jokes at least. Deadshot is also pretty good. This movie way better than the movie version of Suicide Squad that the DCEU had. But that ain't saying much. The movie at the moment is the worst movie I've seen in 2018. So I'll give Suicide Squad: Hell To Pay a 6/10

review: X men days of future past is easily one of the best x men movies of all time and marked the return of Bryan Singer to the franchise after several disappointment entries after his departure. This film is solid and probably underrated featuring great direction, a great story and a large cast that unites the original x men trilogy cast of Patrick Stewart, Ian Mckellen, Hugh Jackman, Halley Berry with the prequel cast of James Mccavoy. Michael Fassbender, Jennifer Lawrence, and Nicholas Hault. All the performances are great notably a delightfully funny and witty small appearance by Evan Peters as Quicksilver, James McAvoys tortured performance as young xavier, and Michael Fassbenders almost superior interpretation of a young magneto rivaling the charismatic Mcckellen. The movie sends Jackmans wolverine back to the past to meet with young xavier played Mccavoy to stop a future apocalypse. This movie is fun as it brillianly goes back to the past and present weaving between the two separate casts and trilogies in an epic way. Jackman is great with the prequel cast serving as the bridge between the two franchises. The movie has its weaknesses as the story can be devoid of logic and a lot of plot holes created by previous entries. Yet it features great drama, and lots of action that turn this movie into a superhero epic. Easily one of the best in the franchise.

review: One of my favorite superhero movies of all time. I just adore this movie so much. I love how it immediately jumps into the plot. No setting up characters, just expositon done right and the best part of the movie is definitely the story and pacing. It's awesome seeing the older and newer X-Men cast and it's such an engaging story (and it's a time travel movie) with perfectly clear high stakes. You're always on the edge of your seat, wondering what'll happen, making the movie unpredictable and it's perfectly paced. No scene is too short or fast. The acting, visuals and action are absolutely marvelous with so many cool mutant powers. It's really compelling as well seeing a broken Charles with a great character arc, a Logan who steps into the role of mentor, an awesome Quicksilver scene and it once again explores the relationship with human and mutants and time so well and that 3rd act is phenomenal. I always wonder how it's going to end. My only complaint is we didn't see much of Wolverine in action but damn is it a masterpiece.

review: I'm gonna be a little too honest here: I bingewatched all the X-Men movies, so I often forget about this movie. Many times I get confused when someone mentions a scene from this movie, and I'm like, "wait, it happened in THIS movie? I thought it happened in First Class/Apocalypse!" And I'd prefer admitting that it's my fault than it being the movie's fault. X-Men: Days of the Future Past is what I'd call the movie that bridges X-Men: First Class with the other canonical movies, and at the same time also helps in eliminating the bad movies like The Last Stand and Origins. The movie begins with, as usual, mutants being attacked and eliminated. So to save all of them, Wolverine goes back in time and stop Mystique from killing Bolivar Trask, a defence contractor. Wolverine reached the 1970s, when he was still a mutant without vibranium. And to set planes in motion, he has to find Charlex Xavier, Magneto, Beast and Mystique. Bolivar Trask used Mystique's powers to create Mutant Hunting Robots. In the beginning they were only meant to be used to fight in the Vietnam war, but seeing how Mystique and Magneto revealed themselves, they decided to use the robots to hunt down the mutants itself. They didn't see whether mutants are also sentient beings or not, they just wanted to have them eliminated. And that's when the roles of money and power play. It was on the order of President Nixon that Bolivar decided to make those robots, which President Nixon had ordered only because of Bolivar's influence. So in a way it was a loop of blame. And when Professor X, Wolverine and Quicksilver reach Magneto to save him, we finally get to see the fabled Quicksilver scene, where he takes down all the prison guards single handedly. It was the most iconic moment from the movie, and no amount of appreciation can praise it as much as it deserves. The modern day scenes were also adding to the tension, and in the end when Mystique is left with the choice whether to kill Bolivar or not, it is a quite tense moment whether the mutants in the modern time will survive or not. In the end we see that all the mutants who had died in the previous movies had also come back to life, and the franchise was brought back to where Bryan Singer had left it in X2. Normally it is very difficult to reboot a franchise (read Sonic 06). Not only do you have to understant the major events that need to ve removed in order to fix the franchise, you also have to make the reboot-turning movie really good, otherwise it will just contribute to being the hot garbage that the other movies of the franchise are. And that's the reason why I believe this movie is underrated. It single handedly fixed a failing franchise, joined the acclaimed prequel into the main timeline and became a success both critically and financiallly. It deserves to be one of the most iconic X-Men movies.

review: Captures both the warmth and depth of the classic book's overall story while also capturing the spectacular land of Narnia that you'd imagine from the book. Well-told with a strong good-vs-evil theme appropriate for children (no blurring of the lines here) and morality lessons about bravery, selfishness vs selflessness, caution with strangers, etc aplenty. Some have argued some of the acting was subpar but it wasn't a big deal to me. The music is appropriately majestic and the action retains your interest throughout. A must-see for famiilies.
mojo_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe

review: Four children from London escape the bombardment during WWII to the home of the Professor. While there, they discover the wondrous world of Narnia inside a wardrobe. The children actors do an excellent job in the lead roles, especially Georgie Henly who played Lucy. Tilda Swinton, James McAvoy and the voice of Liam Neeson are also standouts. This is truly a wonderful adaptation of the book. The special effects are hit and miss, you can tell several heads are giant practical effect masks, some green screen scenes are obvious and some of the character animation is off. But the hits are spot on! Aslan's eyes are beautifully animated as is the rest of him and the Beavers as well. Highly recommend this movie, go check it out!
mojo_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
rt_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe - Movie Reviews

review: C. S. Lewis was the author of the Narnia story series, which was meant to be a "Lord Of The Rings"-type scenario for children. Lewis himself wrote about religion and was a convert to Christianity later in life, but the Narnia series was not necessarily intended to be an allegory about Christianity, contrary to popular myth. Degrading death and rebirth of someone is obviously not exclusive to the Bible. I mention this because the novels (which I haven't read) and the movie are simply epic adventure stories. So how are they on their own merits? The establishing parts are good; siblings living in London during the Blitz are sent to safety in the countryside, and while playing they discover the title magical kingdom. Unfortunately the children don't really engage us, nor does anyone else, and the story is rather confusing. Worst of all is the ending, where the kids have grown into adults during their time there, but when they get back to their home, they are kids again. Huh? Special effects are okay, but that was about it. Go see Peter Jackson's "Lord Of The Rings" instead.

review: The gentlest of young adult blockbusters. It boasts solid CGI and general design, and the adult casting is impeccable. Still, this adaptation's biggest asset is its faithful reminder of how great the original story is. It doesn't change much, and what it does change is largely positive (Edmund's death). It's far from perfect; Peter is annoying, Aslan is a bit tamed down, the battle is overlong, the musical score is bad. Nonetheless, Lewis's brilliance mostly shines through.

review: Book adaptations tend to belong to four categories - the highly flawed commercial successes which the real fans of the book hate with intense passion (Percy Jackson, I'm looking at you), the critical and financial flops (A Wrinkle in Time, Artemis Fowl), films that have a separate passionate fanbase from the book and tend to lean towards the successful kind (Harry Potter is one good example, Winnie the Pooh) and finally - the guys who get picked up, shelved around, are always "in development" and never see the day of light. The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe was neither. It wasn't a Harry Potter, and it wasn't a critical mess. It also was produced, and merited itself even more films. And after doing all this, it stays true to the adaptation. Fair enough, Christian parents would be a little disappointed seeing their favorite theologian novelist's book getting adapted into what is more of a pure light fantasy and less of a biblical allegory. Although Arsalan is still revered in a similar fashion, the overall aesthetic is far more Lord of the Rings than it is The book of John. It is cinematically well-done, from the bombing of London, the cigar-smoking landlord to the insides of the land of Narnia. The characters do tend to be forgettable though. Not from a depth of good acting or that they aren't fleshed enough - they are fleshed way too much. The White Witch is of course my favorite (from a narrative standpoint and not moral or personal whatsoever) when it comes to the main characters, and Arsalan does a pretty decent job too. It has several heart-warming moments to watch and utter "Aww" to, but the only thing it lacks are more LOL moments. Overall, a 3/5 and would say it is pretty fresh.

review: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe This magical fantasy, released in 2005, is a gorgeous screen version of Clive Lewis's novel The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. The film directed by Andrew Adamson turned out to be really beautiful, full of magic, breathe-taking story and interesting characters. Due to expensive and high-quality special effects, the film ended up with a big budget of about $ 180 million. When I first saw this film ten years ago, I was completely captured by this story, and loved it forever. Four children, Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy, are sent by their parents from London to the village to an old professor - a friend of the family. Once, playing hide and seek, the young heroine Lucy discovers a mysterious wardrobe, thanks to which all four find themselves in the fabulous country of Narnia, where fantastic people, animals and creatures live. It turns out that this peaceful country is under the rule of the evil Witch, because of which it is always cold and eternal winter. Children must help King Aslan, the Great Lion, who founded Narnia many centuries ago, defeat the Witch, break the spell and free the inhabitants of Narnia. I wanted to pay attention to the visual effects, special effects, make-up, scenery, the whole atmosphere in the film - everything was done just perfectly. Watching this fantasy, as if you really find yourself in the magical world of Narnia, in which you want to stay forever. To summarize, I want to say that the film is thought-provoking, spectacular and well-filmed.
mojo_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe

review: Long bloody title, but a great film no doubt. I had seen 'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' before but hadn't watched it for years and years, I remembered the vast majority though - it's a memorable film after all. There's a great battle scene in there, some fun characters and strong effects. It's a tad too long, but not by much. It has a nice charm to it also, as they set up Narnia excellently. The quartet of children are very well cast, all four of them suit their roles to a T. Georgie Henley is sweet as Lucy, while William Moseley and Anna Popplewell fulfil the roles of Peter and Susan comfortably. Edmund, meanwhile, is of course annoying, but Skandar Keynes does a good job portraying him. Elsewhere, Tilda Swinton and Liam Neeson are terrific casts as the White Witch and Aslan. Both do great, especially Swinton. James McAvoy, Ray Winstone, Michael Madsen and Rupert Everett are smart choices too. I've, as far as I'm aware, never seen the two sequels so very much look forward to seeing what they have in store for me. They'll do well to match this first film, that's for sure.

review: The film The Lion The Witch And The Wardrobe is good and disappointing at the same time. I love how Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy all work together when in danger they always keep each other safe, and they always support each other. Peter saves Susan and Lucy from the wolf. Also, in the battle, Edmund saves centaurs, fauns, and animals by sacrificing himself and destroying the witch's wand. I also like Lucy. She is a good character because she's kind and forgiving and always wants to help people. She forgave Mr. Tumnus. The parts that aren't in the movie makes me sad because I was really looking forward to seeing some of those scenes, like when they were playing with Aslan in a big ball of love and joy.

review: MOVIE The movie The Lion,The Witch, And The Wardrobe is disappointing. The worst part is that the creators took all the joy out of it and replaced it all with wars and battles. In the book The Lion, The Witch, And The Wardrobe, you don't actually see the battle. Instead you see joy and happiness, but the movie focuses on violence and war. The courtyard scene with giant Rumblebuffin and the lion who said "He said us lions" is missing. So is the scene when the children, who were now adults, talked strangely, for example when Peter said, "For in all my days I have never hunted a nobler quarry." Instead they speak very casually. I do not like how the creators changed so much of the book. It ruined the whole movie this way.
mojo_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
rt_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe - Movie Reviews

review: It is one of the rare cases in which it makes no difference to read the book first or see the film first. Both make the other better, and as an adaptation, the Disney movie is simply flawless. Each line of each scene in the book was accurately transcribed on the screen, also accurately transcribing the emotions and sensations of each moment in the way that C.S.Lewis endeavored to do. But besides being an extremely faithful adaptation to the original, this film also has its universe expanded in a coherent and aggrandizing way to the story it is telling, with several original scenes being created for the script. Scenes that add context, deepen the characters, make what is epic more epic, what is magical more magical and what is deep deeper. It is no exaggeration to conclude that this film is probably the best adaptation of a book ever made.
mojo_name: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe

review: This prequel to Monsters, Inc., tells the story of how Mike and Sully met in college. The biggest draw for the first film was the relationship between Sully and Boo, and while Mike and Sully's relationship was interesting, not continuing to develop Sully and Boo was a disappointment. The choice to make a college fraternity movie out of this franchise is interesting on the same level as making a spy movie out of the Cars franchise. There are also several plot points that do not mesh well with the set up from the first movie. On its own, this movie has some great comedic and emotional moments. The voice acting is great and the animation is amazing as always from Pixar. There is a scene during the third act that shows Mike and Sully sitting in front of a Moon lit lake and it is absolutely beautiful! While this film does not expand the franchise the way it wanted to, this movie is worth your time.

review: Ok so‚Ä¶.this movie has some great moments. Is that enough to call this a great movie? I'm gonna go out on a limb and say no. This movie has two things that I think are truly great, being the theme and the ending. The theme of the natural (Sully) vs the hard worker (Mike) I think is great. They should use that in more of their movies, I wouldn't mind seeing that again. The ending also portrays to this theme, showing how Mike still found his passion in scaring by coaching other monsters. If only the rest of the movie was like that. First, the animation and voice acting is still stellar. The story and everything that has to do with them being in college is boring and predictable. It's just 80s college movie stereotypes, and I don't want to see that in a Pixar movie, I'm sorry, I just don't. Also the jocks vs the nerds stereotype with the scare games is another thing I just don't want to see in a Pixar movie, again, I just don't want to see that‚Ä¶.AT ALL. That made this movie from a good and entertaining one, to barely serviceable. This is just another Brave to me. Just like that movie, I would only watch this movie if you want to say you've seen them all. If not, I'm sad to say, this is another one I would skip. To be honest, this feels like an appetizer before the next big Pixar flick.

review: I never got to know this movie existed. I used to live under a rock back when it released. So the moment I learnt that Monsters Inc has a prequel, I immediately watched it with my sister. We didn't know what we were going to witness other than the fact that the title itself says it's from the time Mike and Sully were in college. And it really stood on our expectations. It's funny, adventurous and has the character development that we want to see in a Pixar movie prequel. This time around Mike is the protagonist. His life is shown from the school days to studying in college and then finally getting a job at Monsters Inc. Seeing him really reminded me of my own days of school, which is the reason why I liked his character so much over here. Sully is like one of those normie guys whom I'd always choose to stay away from in my school/college days. I absolutely hate people like him. And that's what made me side by Mike even more. But eventually as Mike and Sully became friends and took part in the competition, I began liking Sully slowly. He's the kind of a character who may act like a douche, but is not completely bad. He does not behave that way because he himself wants to. He's just doing it because he thinks this is what will make him popular. Coming from a big family he never understood the way normal people behave. And once he became friends with Mike, he slowly began to change. Although he still didn't trust Mike, because of which he cheated to make Mike win by adjusting the dial of the scared child. The ending was actually pretty unexpected. I was thinking they will graduate from college and then become employees at Monsters Inc. After all, the college name sounded just like the company. But the ending seemed completely random and hilarious. They slowly rose up to the ranks, answering the question within the last 30 seconds. I watched this movie about 2 years ago and I have very little memory of it. So I can't exactly remember every single detail that happened in it. I can definitely say that this was a very fun movie, although not exactly memorable. I'd say Monsters University is a good movie, just like all the other Pixar sequels, if you're a fan of the previous movies and want to watch something fun for the whole family. It's quite surprising no one takes its name when talking about Pixar sequels. They only say Cars 2, Finding Dory, Incredibles 2 etc. I wouldn't have even known about it if I didn't open the Pixar Wikipedia page and scrolled through all the names of the movies that I wanted to bingewatch. This movie is definitely something I'd watch again if I get the chance.

review: This felt very much like a generic animated movie stuck in first gear during the first half of the runtime. The new characters were decent, but the story itself didn't feel very original. Voice acting and atmosphere was average. However, the music was nice. The movie starts becoming more focused in the latter stages of the ‚ÄòScare Games' when stakes feel higher and this is where characters begin to develop their one-dimensional personalities. Also, seeing a more realistic art style in the landscape when Mike and Sully visit the human world was unique. I liked the idea of the B-movie cabin in the woods horror scene to scare adults. It gave the movie a fresh change. I didn't find the underlying tones, mood, or humour that you'd expect in a Pixar film, and there was little that would appeal to adult viewers.

review: This review contains spoilers. Monsters University exists. Luckily it exists. Let's clarify immediately that I loved this film to madness. I really like the US collegiate environment and I really enjoyed seeing Monsters Inc's monster world again. So why didn't I give it 5 stars? Because unfortunately the film has flaws, but there are also great merits. First of all, the animation is of great quality and the amount of monsters created is impressive. The moral of the film is the thing that needs to be given more credit. We have always been used to messages like: always follow your dreams, do not be discouraged by difficulties, become someone. And then comes Monsters University which teaches you that we have impassable limits and that we shouldn't believe too much in dreams. Only this, for me, should be shown to all children: it is a really important message. The film is divided into 3 acts: Mike's arrival at university, the scare games and at the end the surprise with the two protagonists who face the human world for Mike's aversion to the fact that he doesn't scare anyone. All three acts are well done. Honestly my favorite is not the third act, as everyone thinks, but the second: all the games are great and Johnny Worthington III, the second act villain, I love it. But let's go now to the painful notes of the film. The film already contradicts itself in its existence: in Monsters Inc Mike says that they met well before university. But here it is necessary to specify how they knew about the sentence and tried to create a link anyway, which however was too forced. So I can perfectly understand why they didn't. The new characters added, except Dean, are poorly characterized and are not given much space. Most of all I would have liked to know more about Johnny's past and why he bullies Mike. Moreover, even the members of the ozma kappa themselves do not have three-dimensionality. Randall, however, forms the lowest point in the characters. I love Randall at Monsters Inc, but they made some serious mistakes here developing him. He is presented to us as kind, shy, however the opposite of how we all know him. So during the vision I wondered how they were going to change his temperament. Well, he becomes a popular monster thanks to Mike and therefore has access to the ROR group (Johnny's fraternity so to speak). So, during the games, I honestly didn't see any gradual changes, but it seems like suddenly, during the final game, Randall totally changed his character. Don't tell me that failing to scare Sulley's retaliation is justifiable. An early-film Randall wouldn't have taken it so badly. If you wanted to radically change Randall, maybe I would have put the background on ROR or I would have already shown a different character at the beginning of the film. Because in my opinion the influence of the RORs is no excuse. The relationship between Mike and Sulley is really well developed, even too much. Perhaps the real problem with the film is precisely that: they thought too much about Mike and Sulley leaving out the other characters. That said, the film, despite its flaws, managed to do the most important thing, which is to make you fall in love with the characters and the film in general. A student plot, Pixar-branded animations but above all a morality worthy of the study make Monsters University a very good film despite the superficiality of the non-main characters.

review: Though not nearly as great as the original, "The Matrix Reloaded" is still a fun film that improves upon the original in some ways though disimproves in several others. Where I think the sequel succeeds is in the action, which is done much better in this movie than in the first. The CGI is also improved upon in this, as is the world-building with the introduction of the teased city Zion. However, where this film falls short in comparison to the first is the story, which feels more predictable and bland than the original. Also, the whole idea doesn't feel as fresh anymore, and the dialogue feels dumbed down. This was still a rather enjoyable film, and a worthy sequel to the amazing first Matrix movie.

review: (Contains spoilers of this one and the first)Well, it was nice. At least, it was better than expected. I thought it would be a disaster but honestly, it was correct without being absolutely fantastic like the first one. I think that the story wasn't good and that is why it wasn't really good. Too much useless moments and it is long for nothing. Honestly, it could have been 1h45 and it would have been better. Also, I think Neo has too much power. I mean, he can be the One without being a mix of Superman, Spider-man, Batman and Black Panther. He revives Trinity, ok. He flies, ok... He fights thousands of Agent Smith, well that is a bit too much. Also, I think the VFX are worst than in the first movie. Some moments were animated like in the Polar express and I didn't like it. I know it was impossible to do it differently but that made me under appreciate the visuals. Now, I really liked the script. It was richer than in the first one. Keanu doesn't just ask questions and there is some really nice lines. Especially from Morpheus. More sci-fi and thought-provoking talks and I like it. To finish, like in the first one, I just love the unrealistic fights because they are so insane, bizarre and nice. I also enjoyed hearing that fantastic voice of Agent Smith. He was dead but we got so much of him and it doesn't bother me at all.

review: Come on guys, this ain't bad. Matrix Reloaded is nowhere near the level of the masterpiece that is the first movie but is it a bad sequel or movie? No. There's some great worldbuilding like the addition of Zion. I love the design and it's awesome seeing the free human city mentioned in the first movie and it was also great seeing the people freed from the Matrix and what they suffered through including some of the politics. The action and choreography of this movie is outstanding with the freeway chase being the standout and while some of the CGI is poor, the effects are incredibly impressive for the most part, the acting is great just like the first movie, more philosophical reasons are discovered like the concept of human choice, cause and effect as well as this idea of reason and these philosophical conversations are interesting especially with the Oracle and Merovignian. The Keymaker is another interesting bit of worldbuilding and I like Trinity and Neo's relationship and seeing their love for one another and we also learned of the origins of the Matrix and contrary to popular belief, I liked the inclusion of the Architect, subverting the story from the supposed chosen one trope that was so insisted by Morpheus. All in all, it's a good sequel. It's really flawed though. There's this dance party in Zion with a ton of overly sexualized characters that's dragged on too long, the plot takes a while to get going and the fact that the movie was split into two did not help. The movie tries to do too much with its ambition and this has the whole Zion plotline as well as the machines invading it sadly forgotten most of the movie and some of the action and philosophical conversations are too long, ruining the pacing. The movie feels kind of tensionless with the lack of threat. The way Neo revives Trinity and discovers his new found power makes no sense . Neo is also so overpowered in this movie now and Agent Smith is brought back somehow and does nothing. The ending is quite unsatisfying, being rushed but frankly, this movie doesn't deserve some of the hate it gets. The first Matrix is way better but this is a good sequel that, while very flawed, has a lot of the great stuff that made the original a masterpiece.
rt_name: The Matrix Reloaded - Movie Reviews

review: This is good but not as a stand alone. I think the love of the first film and the interest in the characters and story carries most of this film. While it is a continuation of the original and seems to pick up where the original left off, it seems off point fo the importance message and mission that ended the second. We do see an expansion off the rebellion and are exposed to more members of the Resistance; however, that is not necessarily a good thing. There is more disharmony than I expected among and between these characters in light of the heroics of the original. Fishburne, Moss, and Reeves are great. Some new characters are very intriguing. Others not so much. While there is more of Agent Smith in some ways- he is much less interesting in others. The fight scenes and visuals are still stellar. The visual effects are spectacular. The music is compelling. This film does not hold up to the first- but no film really could. The real question I keep asking myself is whether this film should have been made at all. Regardless, Neo is one part Anakin Skywalker, one part Paul Atredes, and 100% one of the coolest characters in modern movies.
rt_name: The Matrix Reloaded - Movie Reviews

review: I just rewatched all three of these movies yesterday so now is the perfect time for me to review them. The Matrix Reloaded isn't a bad film at all, it's nowhere near as good as the first movie but there is still a lot about this film that makes it interesting and worth watching. I do have my fair share of complaints about Reloaded but I'll get to those at the end of my review, I'm going to explain what I like so much about this film first. For starters, The Wachowskis took the already visually stunning, intense and masterfully coreographed fight sequences from the first movie and turned everything about them up to 11 for Reloaded. The freeway chase sequence in my opinion is still one of the most suspenseful and intense action sequences in all of modern film, and the fight sequence between Neo & Agent Smith in the park after Neo's conversation with The Oracle is just straight up awesome. Before I first watched this movie as a kid I never thought I would find something like Keanu Reeves fighting a literal moshpit of Hugo Weavings so mindnumbingly entertaining. Sure, a lot of the CGI in that fight scene is kinda cheesy and dated looking rewatching it now almost 20 years after it came out, but I feel like critics who allow stuff like that to take points off of movies as a whole are way too nitpicky. I also really like the introduction to the last human city of Zion in this movie, it has a perfect dystopian feel to it. I also love the way we get to see Neo's powers evolve throughout the film, it has a very special way of slowly showing that Neo is growing to become the most powerful being in all of The Matrix. The sequence at the end of the movie where Neo's visions about Trinity dying come true and he uses his new powers to literally digitize his arm reach inside her body to jumpstart her heart and bring her back to life is really cool. But that is where my affections toward The Matrix Reloaded end and my many problems with this movie begin. First of all and this is my biggest problem with not only this entire movie but also all of The Matrix Revolutions is that it doesn't feel like Neo's story anymore. Reloaded & Revolutions seemed to entirely forget that Neo is supposed to be the main protagonist of these movies, instead he spends pretty much the entirety of both sequels feeling more like a melodramatic side character while the movies shifted all of their focus on Morpheus, Niobe, Commander Lock, and the crews of The Hammer, The Logos and The Nebuchadnezzar. This movie is pretty much all about stupid senseless arguing between Commander Lock, who might I add is one of the most idiotic and hateable characters of this entire franchise and Morpheus. The entire "build-up" to the war in the mediocre excuse for a third film could have been and SHOULD have been a small side-plot. Not the main focus of basically the entire movie. Also, I hate The Architect. That entire sequence needs to be removed from the movie completely. It ruins the mystery of The Matrix by literally showing you who created it. One of the best parts of the first movie was that nobody truly knew where The Matrix came from or how it was operated, by introducing The Architect in his stupid room made of TV screens the directors were literally taking 60% of what makes these movies so cool and shooting it in the face at point blank range. In my review of the first movie I mentioned how much I like the philosophical feeling that presents itself throughout the whole plot. In Reloaded that sense of philosophy is completely gone and instead everybody basically just speaks in riddles for 2 hours & 18 minutes, the worst offenders of this complaint being THE FRENCHMAN, Agent Smith and The Architect. My last problem with this movie overall is Neo & Trinity's romantic relationship. The Wachowskis couldn't write convincing love if someone held a gun to their heads. Whenever these two are on screen together they just make out like high schoolers and throw sappy Valentine's Day card level compliments at eachother and we're expected to believe they have his strong loving relationship just because the movie tells us to think that. AND DON'T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THAT AWKWARD 5 MINUTE LONG SEX SCENE. Also, The Keymaker was completely pointless to the plot besides to guide Neo to The Architect, which is one of the worst plot twists in film history. Anyways, for the most part this movie is entertaining to watch for the action sequences and scenes that actually involve Neo. Other than that, this movie feels more like a spinoff than an actual sequel to the first Matrix movie. 7 out of 10.
rt_name: The Matrix Reloaded - Movie Reviews

review: With the trailer for The Matrix Resurrections hitting Comic Con recently (although still widely unavailable for the rest of us) I had an urge to rewatch the sequels. Since the last time I saw The Matrix both the original directors have come out as trans (Lily and Lana Wachowski) and have since stated that the original film was an allegory about being transgender. It's certainly not a reading I considered at fourteen, I was more sold on the many different types of religious allegories that appeared to be spattered throughout the film. It will be interesting to rewatch now knowing the exact interpretation that the directors intended. Anyway I started with Reloaded. I remember being insanely excited for the film when it came out, and although it's not close in terms of having as many interesting things to say as its predecessor, Reloaded has many aspects to it that still impress. The freeway sequence remains a standout, and Neo's fight with an increasing number of Agent Smith doubles isn't quite as grating as it was the first time round. Critically The Matrix Reloaded was on a hiding to nothing on its release; however good it might have been it wouldn't have been good enough. And although many argue there was no need for these sequels, Reloaded does a much better job of following up The Matrix than it gets credit for. It will be interesting to see how Revolutions holds up; I've always been an apologist for both the sequels despite their backlash from all sides. Perhaps that sort of attitude will lend itself favourably to Resurrections on its release in December this year; I have literally no idea what to expect of it.
rt_name: The Matrix Reloaded - Movie Reviews

review: Even more overrated than The Matrix. How can people not see the lack of substance here? The plot was dull, nonsensical, and took too long to get going, there was far too much dialogue and bad, robotic dialogue at that, which ruined the pacing and made the film boring, there was no character development besides an unnecessary sex scene and some kissing, the acting was mediocre, there was too much CGI, the action sequences were repetitive and largely CGI, the costumes were silly once again, the soundtrack felt like nothing new, and the cinematography and editing were unattractive. Why did Neo become Superman? Where did all the people come from? How do they manage to produce food? How come they weren't found and killed by the machines? Nothing was explained because it couldn't be explained. The film was completely mindless besides the choreography.

review: The MATRIX trilogy remains an absolute landmark work of sci-fi, but the films do feel slightly self-indulgent now, each for different reasons. rt_name: The Matrix Reloaded - Movie Reviews

review: The Matrix Rehashed, I mean, Reloaded, was always going to be a tough sell. Our minds were fully bent by the first film, but there was not much left in the Wachowski bag of tricks for any sequels that would allow them to hit the same highs. More Kung fu. Meh. More bullet time. Meh. More Agent Smith (literally). Double meh. In my view, there was a wasted opportunity to do something different with the Smith character, just as Terminator 2 did with the T800 (Schwarzenegger's character). For example, they could have explored the idea that Agent Smith has become an outlaw program, having been freed within the system by Neo, requiring other characters within the Matrix to assist Neo to destroy the exile program. Instead, they chose more of the same, Neo battles multiple copies of Agent Smith, but this time with unrealistic cgi fight scenes, with a muddled plot that doesn't seem to go anywhere. Spoiler alert: Matrix III dishes up even more if the same. Let's hope Matrix iV brings us something genuinely new.

BUT COME ON, AT THE END CREDIT THEY TOLD YOU THERE WOULD BE A THIRD PART AND TO ANYONE'S NORMAL THINKING PROCESS, THEY WOULD THINK THAT THE CONCEPT WOULD BE WELL-EXPLAINED IN THE THIRD PART AND THEY WOULD BUY THE TICKET TO WATCH IT IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND THE CONCEPT. review: After the runaway success of The Matrix, the Wachowski sisters had the most creative and financial power of their entire career. It's safe to say the anticipation to The Matrix Reloaded was incredible. It was a cultural phenomenon and constantly the topic of discussion during free time at high school. The sequel sees Neo (Keanu Reeves) and his allies race against time before the machines destroy their city of Zion. While seeking the truth of The Matrix, Neo must face a vengeful Agent Smith (Hugo Weaving). Packed with as much visual flair as the predecessor, I clearly remember my jaw hitting the floor at the thrilling action sequences. They're full of energy, kinetic and wonderful to watch. The fight choreography is incredibly varied, mixing hand-to-hand martial arts with guns, and even car chases. The highway sequence is possibly one of the best set pieces of the past decade. The performances from everyone are just as strong as before. Keanu Reeves (Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure) delivers a somber and cool attitude of Neo. Whereas Hugo Weaving (Mortal Engines) is perfectly cast in a career-defining role as Agent Smith. He knows exactly how to best articulate the dialogue. While The Matrix is definitely a superior movie, The Matrix Reloaded is a worthy follow-up.

The Wachowskis do attempt to inject new philosophical ideas but they don't always land. Nevertheless its a triumph of action and style with some interesting new characters like The Architect and Monica Bellucci's Persephone.

review: F9: The Fast Saga - PG-13 (2h 23m) 2021 - Action, Adventure, Crime, Thriller 2.5/5 stars So my thoughts are kinda all over on this one. On one hand, this was exactly what the series is supposed to be. Over the top crazy, I mean the franchise inches towards crazier with each installment. I remember way back when, in the first film when they were stealing TV/VCR combos and having fun street racing. Now they're literally going to space in cars... (with little to no explanation about the issues with that idea.) This one did some fun things with returning characters, some of which I guess survived moments that are now pretty lame if you re-watch the older films. The ending was really interesting, I'm crossed because it kinda felt forced but at the same time was a fun was to pay homage to a character that doesn't appear in the film. As a whole, the story of the film was more than predictable but they never have been. The reason I didn't go lower with the rating is similar to how some of the Amityville sequels get higher ratings than most would think. I don't care if you spend $500 or $500 million making a film, if you know what the film is and play into that, then in my book it's a win. I'll continue to check out this franchise because they're a fun brainless popcorn flick and sometimes that's exactly what you need! I wonder how they'll top going to space! #f9 #thefastsaga

review: Old man 007 has no time to stop for a piss in this return to formulaic form for the franchise. Evil geniuses with evil accents, car chases, a watch that has some sort of a magnet in it, a lair, a staggering array of incompetent henchmen, failing to actually kill Bond‚Ä¶. tick, tick, tick, tick tick. Lovely Bond girls presented in a less attainable or more responsible way than Connery would recognise. Great backdrops, martinis, Aston Martin V8, the Navy, M, Q, other letters, 2*007s; tick, tick, tick. Pheobe Whaller-Bridge clearly worked a bit of magic on the script, adding humour to what would have been a worthy but exhausting affair. It's way better than the dirge that was Skyfall and a nice way of spending an afternoon dozing off your booster vaccination.

review: While I liked Skyfall better I cannot think of a more epic or caring way to close out the Daniel Craig era of Bond than No Time to Die. Craig has brought not just a gritty realism to the Bond but also a humanity that was evident from Casino Royale and only grew as the series progressed. The humanity that was often lacking in period iterations of Bond were on clear display. If I were to criticize this movie it would be that it may have been better served as a 2 part epic rather than an occasionally rushed, but brilliant piece of action/drama storytelling. I highly recommend this movie.

review: An elderly gentleman finally gets to go on an adventure to Paradise Falls. As many people have already said, the first 11:30 of this movie is fantastic! Once again Pixar displays their ability to tell a great story without using a word. Post that eleven and a half minute mark the film doesn't live up to that opening, it isn't bad, just not as great. Highly recommended movie, go check it out!

review: One of the few times I've been in a movie theater where it went totally silent. That beginning montage starts so happy and ends so heartbreaking all with the same tune just slowly morphing into a slower more somber version was brilliant. All you could hear in that silence of the theater was sniffling. A wonderful heartwarming tale of the grouchy old man and the enthusiastic young kid meshed so well together. The only thing I didn't like was that it kind of dragged in the middle.

review: Wow! Last time I saw this animated masterpiece, I must have been like 7 or 8 years old and it was one of those films that I was watching on repeat. I think that what I liked about it when I was this age was principally the visuals. The animation is just fantastic. It is colorful and marks the memory. Also, being full of animals and having a nice and beautiful story probably helped in my appreciation of this movie when I was young. But today, for my first rewatch in lots of years, I've realized how good, punching and perfect this film is. I laughed so hard at some parts, cried at other and felt stressed for some others. The emotions are so much present that I was living all the feelings on earth in only 1h35. Pixar did a PHENOMENAL job on this. From the animation, to the story, to the voices, the feelings it brings and the sort of morale (live adventurous but also keep the adventures apart if you have a love that is stronger). This movies took my tears Up to my eyes and I love it!

rt_name: Ne Zha - Movie Reviews

review: On August 31, 2019, "Ne Zha" made the second largest box-office record of Chinese movies. So you may wonder, what makes "Ne Zha" so popular? "Ne Zha" which was a new released animated movie last summer based on a chinese legendary mythical figure called "Nezha" directed and written by Jiaozi. It is still on trends because of its interesting acting styles and meaningful content. As soon as I saw it, I became a fan of this movie and even watched it twice later. Nezha was chosen to be a reincarnation of a good spirit. However, unfortunately it was replaced with the evilest spirit when he was born. He showed his stubborn and mischievous nature which made the villagers panic. In the process of his growing up, the villagers had always treated him with prejudice and fear, no matter what he thought or did. The prejudice was that monsters in people's hearts can cover their eyes and can't see the truth. Finally, until Nezha tried his best to save the villagers, they really let go of their prejudices and accepted him. The reason why I like it is because it gives us some positive energy about life. Nezha said: "My destiny isn't written in the stars, but held in my hands." You know, maybe we all have our own destinies. However, there are still some parts of our lives that can be changed to be good if our minds are set to be so. So who are you, do you have the final say? We are constantly defined by various occasions and needs. Regarding the truth about ourselves, sometimes we have no say in ourselves. Just like the protagonist Meursault in "The Outsider "by the existentialist master Camus, he has no right to speak on the truth of the case he is involved in. This world is sometimes so ridiculous, and many of us in it just endure silently. Therefore, the explosive moment of "Nezha" must arouse the blood and passion in the hearts of the audience. We need Nezha, even if it's just in the movie. The film retains the essence of Chinese traditional culture, good visual effects; the other is the modernity and sense of humor in character shaping and language style. There is also an ugly side in the film. Compared to the truth, many people are more willing to believe in hearsay and then look at people with colored glasses. Moreover, the writer clearly used "Ao Bing" as a contrast to Nezha, highlighting that whether a man or a devil is an independent choice, rather than a subject that is destined by nature. Generally speaking, I take the view that this Chinese animation is of good quality and worth watching. The final product is fascinating and stunning with great humor, deep emotion, exciting action.
rt_name: Ne Zha - Movie Reviews

review: My fav Chinese animated film.
rt_name: Ne Zha - Movie Reviews

review: The movie of Nezha is set in a Mythical world in China. There is a powerful orb that absorbs all energy, which was meant to be destroyed by Taiyi and Shen, two immortals with great powers. It is known as the Chaos Pearl. The Chaos Pearl is divided into two opposite orbs by Yuan Shi (the primordial lord of heaven) the Spirit Pearl and the Demon Orb. Casting a spell of destruction on the Demon Orb to be destroyed in three years so that it doesn't destroy the world. Yuan Shi gives the order to Taiyi to take the spirit pearl so that it can be born into a human. The spirit pearl was supposed to be born as Nezha however due to Shen switching the orbs a young boy is birthed from the Demon Orb whose demonic nature is apparent. As a young boy, Nezha is loved by his parents who lied to him to tame his demonic nature. He is trained by Taiyi to become a demon hunter and is told that he was born from the Spirit Pearl. Becoming impatient he escapes to hunt demons where he meets Ao Bing (also trained to hunt demons) who was born from the spirit pearl as a dragon and was educated rigorously to become a demon hunter and to beware of humans. They fight together the demon however Ao Bing loses, and Nezha ends up rescuing him. The villagers however misinterpret the situation and blame all the destruction on Nezha due to his demonic nature. Nezha and Ao Bing become friends. However Nezhas's third birthday is coming, his parents throw him a birthday party and force the town to come. Shen visits Nezha before the party and tells him that he has lied to his whole life and that he was born of the demon orb. Nezha feels betrayed and unleashes his demonic powers destroying everything and almost killing his dad however he leaves to await his fate. Shen knows that if Yuan Shi finds out the truth about what had happened. Tat all of the dragon race will be condemned. So Ao bing decides to use his powers to destroy Nezha's village to erase any evidence of the events. Nezha is shown through a vision that his dad had been trying to find a way to remove the curse. In which he takes the curse upon himself so that Nezha could live. Because of this Nezha returns to his village to stop Ao Bing from destroying his village. He defeats Ao bing but spares him. When lighting comes to kill him he surrenders to his fate. However, Ao bing joins him in taking the hit of the lighting. Because of them joining the Chaos Pearl is once again united and can absorb the full hit of the lighting. Taiyi makes it possible for their spirits to survive. This story plays the themes of nature vs. nurture and choice. Even though Nezha was naturally born with a demonic spirit, didn't have many friends, and was feared and hated by his village, he was raised by good parents who loved him, taught him to control himself, and was told that he was born from the spirit pearl. So when Nezha was growing up, he had a pretty positive paradigm about himself, which led him to be able to control his demonic nature and be good. On the other, hand, we see Ao Bing being born from the spirit pearl he was told that he was going to be great, he did however have a rougher upbringing being raised by the king of the dragons and trained by Shen, and like a dragon, he was a hated creature by humans, but he was loved by his kin. When the time comes for them to know, and be faced by who they are. They have the choice to be what their destinies told them to be, or who they were raised to. Having to choose to act upon their natures, what they were told their whole life to be, or choose between good and bad. Nezha decides to act for himself and not let his nature control him, he decides to defend his family, his village, and what is right. What is interesting for me is not Nezha's struggle with choice, but it is Ao Bings. He was way more likely to be good since he was born from the Spirit Pearl, but because of the way he was nurtured to protect his kin he struggles with the choice of helping Nezha save his village or helping Shen. However, in the end, he helps Nezha and also helps Nezha's life as a spirit by uniting their powers. Overall I love this movie because of the character development presented and the message of us choosing to act and not be acted upon. It is also light-hearted and a perfect family night movie. The final rating would be 5 stars!

review: I was surprised by the quality of excellence in all aspects for this animation movie considering it is a Chinese production and in 3D. The store is based on one of their popular mythological character Nezha, a naughty child with godly/demonic powers, reminded me a lot of Lord Krishna as a kid from India Mythology. The story is rich with emotions, character growth, struggle, adventure and laughs. As for the animation itself, even though it is in 3D, it is really good, was refreshing to see how different it was from your standard animation offering from either Japan or Disney/Pixar.

review: This is probably my favorite animated movie ever. I prefer animated movies to live-action and I have watched plenty of animated movies from all over the world. Ne Zha tops all of those movies without a doubt. It's always been difficult for me to pick a favorite animated movie, I actually never even had one before this; Ne Zha is so different from all the others it's refreshing. I'm eager to see what this studio does in the future. Ne Zha is more for teens and adults, so if you're one of those "animation is only for kids" people, I urge you to give Ne Zha a shot; it really is worth it.

It truly is exciting seeing China finally get on board in the animation medium with this high-quality blockbuster.

review: Nezha is one of the most popular and well-known mythical characters in China. Nezha appear in many myths. There are various versions of Nezha's story, and it has been adapted many times in animation and movies. But this adaptation is revolutionary. In the original myths, Nezha is a good boy, but the plot is way more violent. In the myths, Nezha is human baby borne with divine power. His father is indifferent and strict with him. One day, Hezhan caught the Dragon Prince killing children, and then he killed the Dragon Prince (cruelly skinned the young dragon alive). When Dragon King found out, it came to Nezha's revenge. The Dragon King wanted to flood Nezha's hometown with seawater. To protect the village, Nezha committed suicide in front of the Dragon King and his parents. Later, Nezha was resurrected in the lotus and became a God. Then Nazhe destroyed the dragon palace, caught the Dragon King, and became one of the Gods of War. In other versions, Nezha killed a total of 9 dragons. Comparing to the original myth, this movie is chill and light hearted in a good way. The rebellious character of Nezha is fresh and interesting to watch. This story emphasis on the lesson of "choosing your own path", where the original version is more about "unconditional self-sacrifice" and "Â≠ùÈÅì(obedience towards elder family members)". The revised story in the film is more in line with modern values than the original myths.

review: Alfonso Cuaron's Gravity is a roller coaster ride through space, a testament to the resilience of a human being in the face of unimaginable adversity. Sandra Bullock plays Dr Ryan Stone, an astronaut left alone in the vast expanse of space when her colleagues are killed by space debris. The entire film is thrilling, but the first thirty minutes are absolutely remarkable, a crowning achievement in special effects and cinematography. The special effects and cinematography are stellar throughout the film, as are the sound effects and the performance by Bullock. The scene of Bullock making radio contact with a father consoling a crying baby is both inspiring and heartbreaking. Rarely has a film packed so much into an 82-minute running time.
rt_name: Gravity - Movie Reviews

review: As thrilling as "No Country For Old Men", and as beautiful as "Interstellar", Gravity is Cuarons' masterpiece. A titillating survival expedition, filled with hope and optimism.
rt_name: Gravity - Movie Reviews

review: There's no denying that this film is a cinematic masterpiece when it comes to the cinematography and sound design, but there's a distinct lack of story and drive which makes it quite disappointing and monotonous in places. I won't score a 1 as the CGI carried this movie, and helped boost the score ever so slightly. Clooney's character death felt like a desperate attempt to get some action in. Also, Bullock won a nomination for her acting? This wasn't deserved in the slightest, mostly grunting, heavy breathing, and terrible one liner clich√© comments. There is a heart-racing premise and there are indeed incredible special effects, but it falls short and mostly at the hands of the actors and narrative arc.

review: It was always beyond me why critics wet themselves for this movie. Is being a technical masterpiece enough? Without the nads to just let this be a survival story Gravity throws out some of the least funny and cringe inducing dialogue I've encountered. My biggest fear through the film was that Bullocks Botox would zit explode at zero gravity. Obviously pressured by the studio the coming together of the two stars on screen is additionally ridiculous in an already pointless endeavor. Additionally - all the movies visual greatness is lost on any Home Screen. If you want a survival movie that gets it right - All is Lost. The Bullock - Clooney smugness ooozes like a Zenomorphs slime from the screen in Gravity.

review: Gravity boasts some of the strongest visuals around, but threadbare characters and some hiccups in the writing and Bullock's performance when she must perform by herself without the solid Clooney hinder the overall quality of the piece. The film is short but drags in the middle and becomes carried away in its own spectacle. For some, I have no doubt that this is captivating, but it lacks the substance necessary with Cuaron not focusing on building strong or particularly likable characters. A shame, due to the same man's almost faultless direction.

review: I did the full treatment on this one, 3D IMAX. I was blown away by the photography and the pacing of the story. When I left the theater, my legs felt wobbly, like jelly. I got to the parking garage, got in my car and right before I was about to start it my head suddenly felt woozy and I started laughing and controllably. And then I realized what was happening - oxygen deprivation. For almost an hour and a half my pulse had been racing non-stop, my metabolism in overdrive and my breath quick and shallow. That was when I realized just how much of a thrill ride I had been on.
rt_name: Gravity - Movie Reviews

review_date: The movie is a stunning exercise in high budget production trying to save a hot mess of a film. The films beautifully constructed shots and editing is actively being detracted from by the absolute disregard of high school level physics, a story that couldn't be less engaging and is the most basic accumulation of stereotypes (US good, Russia bad, China stupid; mentioning deceased family as a tear-jerker; sacrifice of a main character to heighten the stakes....) to try and construct a semblance of relatability for audiences. It is an affront to modern space technology, a premise that should've been outdated even in cold wars films, and a soundtrack that does nothing but horror-style tremolo strings rising in pitch slowly for 90 minutes straight. In general, the only "thrill" achieved by the movie to make it actually fit the description of "Sci-Fi Thriller" was the soundtrack desperately hammering every single horror staple home to a nauseating degree. Combine this with the unfitting joke-scenes completely subverting any seriousness that might have been left, and what remains is a hot mess of garbage that looks somewhat beautiful. How this movie won 7 academy awards is beyond me.

review: It's a very visually stimulating movie. It's beautiful to look at. But there's not much going on here. Even at it's very short run-time, it still felt too long. And yes, I am aware that centripetal force could have pulled him away but there were several shots that show they obviously were not spinning so that's not a valid theory here. They killed off Clooney's character just because they needed some drama. The rest of the movie is just things going wrong over and over and the protagonist finding ways to narrowly overcome it on the way to a predictable ending with some pretty forced emotion. I enjoyed the first 30 mins but my interest wore out after Clooney's character was inexplicably killed off.

review: I remember deciding to watch this movie in cinemas because critics were all praising it as one of the best movies of that year. I watched it in IMAX 3D and remember being blown away by the movie. It won: Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Visual Effects, Best Film Editing, Best Original Score, Best Sound Editing, and Best Sound Mixing at the Oscars which is a lot of awards. The synopsis is "Dr Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) is a medical engineer on her first shuttle mission. Her commander is veteran astronaut Matt Kowalsky (George Clooney), helming his last flight before retirement. Then, during a routine spacewalk by the pair, disaster strikes: The shuttle is destroyed, leaving Ryan and Matt stranded in deep space with no link to Earth and no hope of rescue. As fear turns to panic, they realize that the only way home may be to venture further into space". I've decided to rewatch it on a whim but this time on my home TV. The question is if this movie is overrated or deserving of its accolades. Let's talk about the concept first, it's great. A survival movie in space, with no monsters or anything like that, is such a great concept that has not been done before or since its release. The movie perfectly illustrates the horror but also the beauty of space in a way that surprisingly meshes well together. On that note of the beauty, the cinematography is amazing. A lot of amazing cinematography is usually using real shots but Gravity does it all through CGI. It shouldn't work as CGI is quite obvious and bad CGI can even take you out of the movie but Gravity doesn't "fall" in that category. There are a lot of gorgeous shots that feel like paintings and this is partially thanks to the amazing visual effects. The set design for the space ships are claustrophobic and further emphasise the loneliness within this movie. The score is great and elevates the tension in the scenes where the score is prominent but during the more hopeful scenes, the score is more orchestral and beautiful. The movie doesn't rely on the score too much and sometimes just lets the silence of space or the breathing of the astronauts to suck the audience into the movie and it works. The movie is visually spectacular but what about the characters and story? The movie is revolved around Dr Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) who is our point of view character. For the most part, the movie makes us care about her because of the situation she is in and that is fine. However, the director (Alfonso Cuar√≥n) decided to include a scene that elaborates on Ryan Stone's backstory on Earth. This is a good choice as it makes the audience more sympathetic with her and more understanding of why her personality is what it is or why she does certain actions or choices in the movie. Matt Kowalsky (George Clooney) is a sort of anchor character that support Ryan throughout the movie. He has a contrasting personality to Ryan as he is funny and charismatic yet due to being more experienced is also one who guides Ryan. I like the dynamic between the two of them and when both of them are interacting it's funny or heartwarming. I also have to praise Sandra Bulluck as she does a great job in carrying this movie. Her performance whenever she is struggling in space feels genuine and I can feel the fear and panic just from the tone of her voice. She also delivers in the emotional moments that bring the scene to life. She was deserving of that best actress nomination at the Oscars. George Clooney does a pretty good job as well. Although, he mostly just plays Matt as the witty and charming guy. I do like it when the two are together, George overshadows Sandra which sounds weird but that is exactly what it should be in terms of who their characters are and what the plot is asking. I don't have many flaws with the movie that aren't just nitpicking but I do think the fact that Dr Ryan Stone seems to constantly panic in the first half of the movie kind of weird. Dr Ryan Stone just seems to not know the basics of being in space so know it all Matt Kowalsky constantly has to tell her stuff that I think she should've known. From a movie perspective, I get why this choice was made so that the audience can easily understand things about space but it could've handled way better in my opinion. Additionally, we get some backstory on Dr Ryan Stone but we don't get anything on Matt which I find a bit odd and lessens the impact of a certain scene. Unfortunately, I do think a lot of the impact this movie has is sadly lost because I am not watching it in a cinema. You could argue that with a lot of movies but for me watching this throughout certainly made me think "this would be way better in a cinema". In conclusion, I still really enjoyed the movie. Yes, the movie is impressive because of its style but in terms of substance, it certainly is lacking. However, the movie is just so visually spectacular that I don't mind it. Furthermore, a lot of great movies such as "Dunkirk" and "1917" do similar things to Gravity and they are both great movies as well. Gravity still is one of the best space movies to have come out in the last 20 years. I feel this movie accomplishes a lot with visual effects and space cinematography. A lot of people might not be talking about this movie anymore but for me, I certainly will still remember it.

review: While the suspense and intrigue in this film are outstanding, the oh-so-convenient plot holes or cinema sins sprinkled throughout the movie (and particularly towards the end) made me figuratively roll my eyes. There's one scene involving a "living" Arnim Zola that is simply ridiculous. The rest of the movie, though, features an immense amount of smart dialogue and multiple memorable scenes. Cap still stands for honor and integrity in this modern world that tries to blur the line of "right" and "wrong". So overall a great film, but watching it a second time, it was not as great as I originally considered it (five stars originally).

review: Steve Rogers is one of the best characters to come out of MCU. He's paired up with Natasha "Black Widow" in this story. I love her fighting style and 'grit' but her character is simply not given enough rope to work with - I guess she needs to remain 'mysterious' until her own movie. As a result their relationship fleshes out in a way I understand but do not "feel". By contrast, the Captain America figure is laid bare and we can see the different factions and emotions pulling at his deep seeded loyalty. I like this story as it gives a setting to his moralistic wrangling and, like us all, he just wants to see his choices make a difference and to feel like he has agency over his own life. The Winter Soldier idea is cool - the whole Shield is a shell that has grown the enemy within is not new, but was decently executed. Falcon seems to survive too easily. Does he even have 'superpowers'? He take a ton of punishment if not. The movie is too long - of course, all of these MCU movies are too long for an action flick. But I take at least two sittings to watch anything these days since I'm on my own couch anyway, so no big deal. I knocked off a star due to that length and the fact that very important dialogue to halfway decent plot is spurted out after a gut punch, or growled through gritted teeth, or whispered while explosions go off in the background, or shouted while a crescendo of 'dramatic' music flares too often.

review: "Breaking Dawn Part 1" just loads it on even more that the previous three films - it being wooden acting, bad dialogue and stilted plotting. It all starts out with the forest wedding of Bella (Stewart) and Edward (Pattinson). This then turns in to a honeymoon with unanticipated consequences. Just way too much extended scenes and drab dialogue that should have been cut. And the inability of the two leads to barely go through the motions of acting at being in love is galling. Add to this a plot sequence that I won't give away, yet it just further adds to this saga being a mockery of 'values'. Now, most of all I blame the author Stephanie Meyers for hoisting this on us all.

review: This fourth installment I loved because it's two movies broken down from the last book in the series. Bella and Edward have no more enemies to face so they can finally enjoy their happily ever after. Or so we think... Breaking Dawn Part 1 peels back another layer of the human vampire world to show us how dangerous it is when the two world's are consummated. Bringing in elements of Bella's human lifestyle with Edward's vampire lifestyle as a married couple brings about deadly consequences.

review: After two movies in the series I didn't like, I was surprised to say that the first part of "Breaking Dawn" is pretty watchable. A lot of people and reviewers prepared me for a boring movie in which nothing happens but that's not what I felt from the overall package. Sure, the movie is just as cheesy and ridiculous in its first half and I did find myself rolling my eyes during it. However, once the main plot of the movie kicks in halfway, I thought it was pretty solid. The pace moves much quicker and the focus is taken off of the romance just for a little bit, and the movie is better for it. I am not saying this is a great movie as it still has many technical issues in terms of acting and writing, but I will say it is far better than anything this franchise aside from the first movie.

review: I actually did enjoy the wedding and honeymoon of this movie. I know Edward gets a lot of flak for acting like an emotionally abusive boyfriend and Bella's shown to be just as flawed with or without him and people aren't wrong about that but Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson do share surprisingly good chemistry during this section of the movie. Perhaps it's not all that surprising seeing as how this was from the director of the live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast. Visual effects ain't half-bad either. Then Bella gets pregnant. This is where it all goes downhill for me. We spend the rest of the movie at the Cullens' house once Edward and Bella leave Brazil, with a few scenes that take place in either the woods or Charlie Swan's house and I'll just say that the whole pregnancy conflict honestly doesn't feel all that interesting given that the stakes don't feel particularly high. The action being dialed down to zero compared to the relatively decent asskicking in Eclipse doesn't help one bit. The "Part 1" of the title is an incredibly transparent attempt to cash in on the success of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows which were both critically and commercially successful (I personally consider it to be my favourite Harry Potter movie but only if counted as one movie). And I'm sorry, a well-intentioned anti-abortion message just doesn't seem like enough to warrant the adaptation of the final book being a two-parter. Give Deathly Hallows some credit, at least there was some epic and visually stunning wizard-vs-wizard action and I actually do care about those characters and understand how high the stakes were there. And the anti-abortion message would be fine if not for the fact that the concept of imprinting means that Jacob falls in love with a creepy CGI - still better than that animatronic they were initally going to use and fortunately the uncanny valley only comes in affect when we see her up close - baby. Gee, why don't we hear a lot from Taylor Lautner anymore when his character will likely never live that down? Breaking Dawn Part 1 is not a good movie and has its fair share of silly moments, most notably the wolves speaking telepathically when there was no indication that wolves could ever actually do that in earlier installments plus it looking siller than if the VFX artists decided to animate lip movement, but at least Part 2 has an epic battle...though I do know the big twist about it.
mojo_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1

review: Twilight Breaking Dawn Part 1 is a movie from the Twilight saga which originally is a serie of 4 books. They made 5 movies out of it. In my opinion it's a quite good fantasy movie but more made for young adults and teenagers. This movie was directed by Bill Condon and released the 18th of november 2011. The 3 main actors are Kristen Stewart ((Isa)Bella Swan) , Robert Pattinson (Edward Cullen) and Taylor Lautner (Jacob Black). In this movie Edward and Bella get married, she unexpectedly got pregnant during their honeymoon. This twist causes a lot of debates and fights between the recently married lovers and between the vampires and werewolves. The baby could cost Bella's life. The actors are believable, their acting skills are better than in the previous movies thus as the screenplay. They respected the books well. The movie is well shot, the camera angles are good : mostly close shot, extreme close up at the right moments (extreme close up on Bella's eyes at the end, the last image of the movie), Upward and Downward shots during the duel between the Alpha wolves, establishing shot during the wedding to show the beauty of the place and all the guests,... The soundtrack is very, very good, it's mostly alternative/ indie rock songs and a piano melody throughout the whole movie. There are percussions adding to the piano melody when actions are happening. The special effects (wolves' transformation) and make up are good too, all the Cullen have a really pale face and pregnant Bella needed to look very sick and skeletal and it is very well done. So if you're looking for good fantasy movies, I can only suggest you the Twilight saga and especially the 2 latest one.

review: "New Moon" is a real step down from the mediocre "Twilight". The worst aspect of this film - it bludgeon the audience with a Romeo and Juliet undertone and self harm as an antidote to breaking up - not a good message for teens. It has way too heavy an emphasis on the whole tortured separation between Bella (Stewart) and Edward (Pattinson), with Stewart even more wooden than in the first film and Pattinson almost catatonic. The only real plus is the added twist of hunky Jake (Lautner) 'dogging' Bella - who is just shameless in how she leads him on. The near finale in Italy really amped it up but not enough to save the film. Much, much too long - could have easily cut 30 minutes or more.

review: New Moon, the second instalment in the Twilight Saga, is probably not for anyone who is not remotely interested in the original story. It is not a standalone film. There is much more action (although balanced out by the extreme inaction of Bella's severe depression of the first third). Chris Weitz definitely made this a more polished and big-budget looking film than the original. Although whether the polish ultimately adds or distracts from the love story is an interesting question, there are some really beautiful scenes (especially the Italian scenes with the Volturi). The actors are not as painfully awkward and have become more comfortable in their characters and with each other and that does make the the entire viewing experience better. New Moon gets a lower score, because it's not my favourite segment of the story.

review_date: When I watched the first Twilight film I felt that it was bland and uninteresting in every way, and one thing I most certainly did not feel was interest in what happens next. It simply doesn‚Äôt feel like an ongoing saga after that first film, so I was curious to see how they would manage to continue the story when they got to New Moon. Well, it‚Äôs certainly just as boring. The one and only thing I will commend this movie for is that they at least addressed in some small way the general creepiness of the Edward-Bella relationship. Sure they just mention it in passing, and try to laugh it off, but there is a moment when they talk about the fact that a man that is literally hundreds of years old is seducing a teenager. Aside from that, there are no redeeming qualities in this film. The first big flaw in New Moon is that a large chunk of the movie involves Edward leaving and all the relationship stuff being taken over by Jacob. This is a problem because Robert Pattinson could act better than Taylor Lautner in his sleep. Lautner actually manages to be worse than Kristen Stewart, and I didn‚Äôt think that was possible. He is utterly devoid of charisma, and never once convinces me that he is falling in love. Combine that with Kristen Stewart‚Äôs expressionless staring into the middle-distance and you have the worst love story imaginable. As part of this stupid relationship we get to see Bella once again proving herself to be utterly clueless. Despite constant blatant hints and obvious clues, she is simply dumbfounded that werewolves exist. However, the more egregious problem with New Moon, and the reason it made me actively mad, is how it handles the break-up of Bella and Edward. I know it can be devastating to have your heart broken, but this film is so committed to the idea that these two are soulmates and have some supernatural bond, it sends ridiculously harmful messages to teens everywhere. Not only is Bella reduced to wailing in such a dramatic fashion that a responsible father would probably force her to spend time with a therapist, but it gets worse than that. At the idea of never being together again, both members of this couple feel that suicide is their only hope. It‚Äôs dark and depressing, and exactly the opposite of what we should be teaching young people. I don‚Äôt have much more to say about New Moon, because not much else happens in the movie.
